relations.Subject: chart
relations.Description:
The bar chart shows the proportion of a country's land 
area in each of these classes and the global distribution of land area 
across the classes (for comparison).

relations.Subject: chart
relations.Description:
The bar chart 
shows the distribution of the country's land area in each of these classes 
compared to the global distribution of wind resources.

relations.Subject: chart
relations.Description: The chart shows the average NPP in the country

relations.Subject: trade
relations.Description:
Energy trade includes all 
commodities in Chapter 27 of the Harmonised System (HS).

relations.Subject: Disparities
relations.Description:
Disparities between urban and rural areas, gender 
inequality, outward migration and high climate change exposure further impact the country’s 
resilience, competitiveness and well-being.

relations.Subject: hostilities
relations.Description:
The recent large-scale military hostilities in the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict area caused a 
massive displacement from Nagorno-Karabakh to Armenia.

relations.Subject: thousands
relations.Description:
Tens of thousands of them lost 
their homes and productive assets.

relations.Subject: escalation
relations.Description:
The escalation has also left a significant impact on border 
communities, particularly in Syunik and Tavush regions of Armenia.

relations.Subject: Armenia
relations.Description:
Armenia has undergone a profound transformation since independence, including after 
the peaceful transition of power in 2018 which triggered renewed commitments to a humancentred governance system, investments in human capital and the realization of the human 
rights agenda.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP plays a key role in ensuring a coherent United Nations strategy for collective 
impact, under the overall leadership and coordination of the Resident Coordinator.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP underwent a sense-making review in 2020 to identify coherent cross-portfolio 
areas for action.

relations.Subject: Examples
relations.Description:
Examples include the nexus of education, technology, inclusion and jobs, 
particularly for women in science, technology, engineering and mathematics; innovative 
approaches to public service delivery; and participatory democracy, active citizenship, youth 
empowerment and citizen engagement.

relations.Subject: programme
relations.Description:
The country programme will support all three pillars of the United Nations Sustainable 
Development Cooperation Framework (UNSDCF): (a) people’s well-being and capabilities; 
(b) green, sustainable and inclusive economic development; and (c) responsive and effective 
governance.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Particularly, UNDP will address multidimensional poverty by building a deeper 
and more holistic understanding of what poverty and vulnerability mean in the postCOVID-19, conflict reality and work across sectors to address the deprivations that leave 
people behind.

relations.Subject: snapshots
relations.Description:
Regular human development snapshots will unpack emerging priorities, 
drawing attention of policymakers through white papers and provoking public discourse 
through awareness-raising.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support the Government’s future-proof strategic 
planning by embedding foresight and scenario design at national and subnational levels, 
including in crisis preparedness.

relations.Subject: advantages
relations.Description:
The comparative advantages of UNDP include the ability to collect,
manage and analyse data and leverage digital solutions and innovative approaches to help 
the country transition towards risk-informed and evidence-based development.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description: UNDP plays an important role in joint programming and implementation in Armenia.

relations.Subject: platforms
relations.Description:
The platforms have influenced the UNDP approach
to innovation globally and efforts to scale this approach will be further explored during this 
programme cycle through South-South and/or triangular cooperation.

relations.Subject: Armenia
relations.Description:
The vision for the country programme is for Armenia to become a more cohesive, 
inclusive, just and resilient society supported by governance systems that use evidence, 
citizen-centred innovation and partnerships to ensure social, economic and environmental 
sustainability and prosperity for all.

relations.Subject: crisis
relations.Description:
The compound crisis has exacerbated issues in Armenian society that limit potential, 
competitiveness and capabilities at both individual and institutional levels.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will focus 
on a more future-oriented and integrated way of helping to shape and realize a new narrative 
for Armenia.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This means an increased focus on understanding and tackling pre-existing and 
emerging vulnerabilities and risks in the crisis setting and an upper-middle-income context, 
many of which were revealed by the socioeconomic impact assessment of COVID-19.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support Armenia to reimagine and evolve its governance systems, making them 
more agile, effective, service-oriented and shock-resilient, underpinned by a strong civic
culture and linked to real investments in human capital development.

relations.Subject: pathway
relations.Description:
The pathway to sustainable and inclusive socioeconomic development will entail 
initiatives that promote early recovery and community resilience, including in border 
communities, targeting the most vulnerable groups such as war veterans, persons affected by 
conflict, women and children.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will contribute 
to increasing competitiveness and connectivity in Armenia, thus helping to mitigate negative
migration trends.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will further expand its work to strengthen livelihoods, promote a predictable, fair and 
competitive business environment and build social cohesion and resilience in areas affected 
by the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict.

relations.Subject: Support
relations.Description:
Support will include: (a) improving preparedness for socioeconomic and environmental 
shocks in rural communities and secondary cities; (b) the transition from subsistence 
agriculture to value addition, processing and precise agriculture using climate-smart, green 
and digital technologies, including irrigation systems; (c) investments in small and mediumsized enterprises, local start-up initiatives and tourism development; (d) boosting 
entrepreneurship, especially for women, and facilitation of trade, investment and exports; 
(e) income-generation and employment initiatives, including rehabilitation and integration 
into social and economic life for war veterans, wounded and disabled during the recent 
military escalation in the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict area; and (f) the development of a 
future-proof labour market.

relations.Subject: pathway
relations.Description:
The pathway to environmental 
sustainability and resilience will comprise efforts to mainstream environmental issues into 
national and regional development processes, thus helping the country to transition into a 
low-carbon, resource-efficient, resilient and socially-inclusive green economy that is able to 
adapt to and mitigate the effects of climate change.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This will require all-of-society engagement, environmental education, behavioural 
changes, new types of economic and fiscal instruments and public-private partnerships, 
including tapping the potential of the country’s tech sector.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will address energy
poverty and insecurity by investing in energy infrastructure, unlocking retrofit markets for 
energy-efficient and renewable sources and facilitate access to international climate financing mechanisms for mitigation and adaptation, including through climate budgeting 
frameworks.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will pay particular 
attention to the environment-health nexus by mainstreaming a ‘one-health approach’ into 
cross-sectoral policies, financing and actions.

relations.Subject: pathway
relations.Description:
The pathway to democratic governance and gender equality includes efforts that will 
help strengthen trust in governance systems and service delivery capacity in Armenia.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will promote participatory decision-making; strengthen the notion of the citizen 
as the ‘client’ of public institutions; support access to education, learning and self-realization; 
support ambitious future-proof strategies which build on people’s collective aspirations; and 
build social cohesion and help to foster a new social contract.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This includes the creation of psychosocial and economic support mechanisms and 
the provision of medical care, particularly for war veterans.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will also promote 
transformation (including digital) of the Parliament and other institutions to enhance checks 
and balances and ensure a ‘whole-of-government’ approach, strengthened separation of 
powers and cross-party work.

relations.Subject: Parliament
relations.Description:
The Parliament will play a key 
role, serving as an important platform for evidence-based policymaking and citizen 
engagement.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This will include efforts to dismantle structural barriers and 
promote the leadership and wide participation of women and youth in decision-making and
help the Government to ensure that its strategies, plans and programmes are genderresponsive.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
In 
line with the reform of the United Nations development system, UNDP will provide 
integrated policy and programme solutions; support the development of an integrated 
ecosystem for collection and analysis of data on the Goals; support the development of 
evidence-based policies and frameworks aligned to the Goals using state-of-the-art tools for 
data collection, modelling and forecasting; and transfer knowledge, behavioural insights and 
innovation to help pioneer new ways of ‘doing development’”.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Specifically, UNDP will 
pioneer an innovative portfolio approach to the development of the country’s secondary 
cities, using innovative practices for reimagined urban development.

relations.Subject: Government
relations.Description:
UNDP will also work 
closely with the Government to create links between policies, planning and budgeting 
processes and the Goals, and deploy innovative mechanisms to leverage partnerships and 
multiple sources of development finance.

relations.Subject: programme
relations.Description:
The programme will prioritize co-designing a road map for an integrated national 
financing framework to help the Government mobilize the resources needed to realize 
development priorities.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will initiate dialogues between the Government, the private 
sector and investors to provide a common understanding of financing and investments for 
the Goals; stimulate innovative solutions through the implementation of impact acceleration 
programmes; and provide platforms for developing and piloting innovative financing tools 
such as ‘pay for success’ mechanisms or impact bonds.

relations.Subject: ownership
relations.Description:
National and local ownership, diverse partnerships and deployment of local capacities 
will be priorities.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will expand its collaboration with all branches of the Government,
including through exploring government co-funding modalities, and seeking to enlarge its 
network of civil society and development organizations, media, innovation centres, think
tanks, universities, the private sector, diaspora organizations and others.

relations.Subject: Fund
relations.Description:
The Adaptation Fund, the 
Global Environment Facility, the Green Climate Fund and other vertical multilateral funds 
will remain critical partners, with a vision to scale up existing and introduce new 
programming areas in line with government priorities.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
In line with the reform agenda of the 
United Nations, UNDP will expand its portfolio of inter-agency partnerships, especially 
around the issue-based coalitions on social protection, food security and environmental 
sustainability, with a focus on supporting cohesive and integrated United Nations action, 
under the leadership of the Resident Coordinator.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will champion South-South and 
triangular exchange, facilitating sharing of knowledge and experience on such topics as 
disaster risk reduction, innovation and private sector development.

relations.Subject: thinking
relations.Description:
Systems thinking will underpin this work, ensuring holistic 
approaches to complex problems.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
To ensure agility and an effective response to underlying programmatic risks in Armenia, 
including the complex regional context, socioeconomic disparities, climate change and 
vulnerability to natural disasters such as earthquakes, UNDP will strengthen its procedures 
for risk recognition, mitigation and diversification.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
In line with global priorities, UNDP will enhance its focus on thought leadership, 
strengthening capabilities related to data and research, digital solutions, policy analysis and
innovative financial tools.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will tap the potential of volunteering, local and diasporabased expert networks, the private sector and inter-office exchanges as sources of skills and 
expertise.

relations.Subject: document
relations.Description:
This country programme document outlines the UNDP contributions to national results 
and serves as the primary unit of accountability to the Executive Board for results alignment 
and resources assigned to the programme at country level.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Drawing lessons from the independent country programme evaluation and country office 
evaluations, UNDP has strengthened its learning and adaptive management policies, thus 
becoming a more agile and effective partner of choice.

relations.Subject: framework
relations.Description:
In addition to the results and resources 
framework and project result frameworks to monitor outputs and outcomes, the UNDP social 
and environmental standards and accountability mechanism will be used to identify, monitor 
and mitigate risks.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
In line with the recommendations of the independent country programme evaluation, 
UNDP has enhanced its monitoring and evaluation frameworks and staff capabilities and will 
aim for higher-quality evaluations to inform programming and decision-making and promote 
learning.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP uses specific, measurable, achievable, relevant and time-bound indicators to 
monitor outputs and results.

relations.Subject: management
relations.Description:
Stronger results-based management, together with 
communication and outreach, will ensure more effective reporting on impact and partnership 
achievements.

relations.Subject: industry
relations.Description:
Global energy industry has entered a decisive phase of transition, where an increasing number of supply options,
newer energy carriers and the growing demand, contribute to increase the complexity of the industry.

relations.Subject: Lanka
relations.Description:
Sri Lanka
too, will face this transition during the next few decades, and the energy industry in transition will fuel the
growing economy of the country, opening many frontiers and opportunities.

relations.Subject: policy
relations.Description:
This policy spells out ways and
means of steering the energy sector in transition to power the nation and its social market economy,aiming at
higher levels of stability, security, affordability and sustainability with the least environmental burden,and provide
a fertile ground for all public and private enterprises, homes and institutions to flourish in a future, where
energy will not be a constraint.

relations.Subject: drive
relations.Description:
The government’s drive to reach the upper middle-income
level within this decade intensifies the role of energy in Sri Lanka’s economy.

relations.Subject: Lanka
relations.Description:
Sri Lanka maintains a comparatively lower energy intensity of economy, using 0.47TJ of commercial energy to
produce onemillion LKR of GDP2.

relations.Subject: Lanka
relations.Description:
Sri Lanka has reached the important milestone of 100%
electrification, thereby fulfilling the goal of providing modern energy sources to all the citizens.

relations.Subject: resources
relations.Description:
Water resources serve multiple needs, power generation being the third priority
after drinking water and agricultural demand, further complicating issues related to projects such as the Mahaweli
Stage II development.

relations.Subject: generation
relations.Description:
Water resources serve multiple needs, power generation being the third priority
after drinking water and agricultural demand, further complicating issues related to projects such as the Mahaweli
Stage II development.

relations.Subject: Lanka
relations.Description:
Sri Lanka weathered many energy crises over the last few decades due to resilience garnered from many deep
roots.

relations.Subject: roots
relations.Description:
These roots can be identified as the impressive use of biomass resources, year-round sunshine and
higher rainfall, combined with frugal lifestyle of her people and the small geographical expanse of the country.

relations.Subject: reliability
relations.Description:
The reliability of energy systems has attracted services sector to the country, leveraging
more economic benefits to the country with the least possible input of energy.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This has caused a structural
change in the economy towards services, in sharp contrast to other developing economies experiencing steep
growth in the energy intensity of economy.

relations.Subject: Reliability
relations.Description:
Reliability and affordability of both indigenous and global energy supplies will be the most desirable ingredient
in this economy in transition.

relations.Subject: Biomass
relations.Description:
Biomass,
probably the most important energy resource, will play an even more valuable role by making a transformation
to a convenient fuel for household use and a dependable resource for industrial thermal energy supply.

relations.Subject: Electricity
relations.Description:
Electricity will take the pride of
place in the quest for discovering new energy carriers, drawing resources from increasing amounts of indigenous
resources, whilst securing supply routes for global resources.

relations.Subject: policy
relations.Description:
This policy will pave the way to realise the vision of Sri Lanka in achieving carbon
neutrality and complete transition of all the energy value chains by 2050.

relations.Subject: policy
relations.Description:
The policy provides the necessary
space for establishing key manufacturing industries supplying sustainable energy technologies to the local market and forge alliances with other developing countries through South-South cooperation by developing
knowledge products and sustainable energy technologies in line with Goal 7 of the SDGs.

relations.Subject: document
relations.Description: This policy document has three sections:

relations.Subject: Framework
relations.Description: The Results Delivery Framework, elaborating the specific actions, milestones and the institutions responsible

relations.Subject: policy
relations.Description: This policy supersedes all previous policies, strategies,plans and guidelines published from time to time.

relations.Subject: gas
relations.Description:
Considering the recent price profiles, natural gas would be the next fossil fuel option for the country
to broaden diversity.

relations.Subject: capacity
relations.Description:
3.1.4 Percentage installed power generation capacity from a single imported fuel shall not exceed 50%
of the total installed firm capacity to safeguard against geopolitical uncertainties and fuel price
shocks.

relations.Subject: Maintenance
relations.Description:
3.1.9 Maintenance of strategic fuelreserves in strategic locations in the country will be made mandatory
for all key players in electricity and petroleum industries.

relations.Subject: services
relations.Description:
Additionally,
premium services will be offered to customers who are willing to pay for such higher service
quality levels.

relations.Subject: that
relations.Description:
The government will identify and provide transparently funded subsidies to target groups of energy
users in household, industrial and commercial sectors,that deserve special consideration owing to
their economic standing and contribution to national economic development priorities.

relations.Subject: efficiency
relations.Description:
3.4.17 Energy efficiency will be a primary concern in retrofits, and new building designs will be evaluated
for their energy performance on a mandatory basis.

relations.Subject: efficiency
relations.Description:
3.4.19 Fuel efficiency of vehicles would be a key consideration in deciding applicable taxes on vehicles to
encourage a higher efficiency vehicle fleet.

relations.Subject: person
relations.Description:
3.6.10 Necessary Health, Safety and Environmental (HSE) standards will be introduced and relevant
regulations enforced, making it an offence for a person to operate any energy related infrastructure
without complying with the prescribed HSE standards.

relations.Subject: governance
relations.Description:
Good governance in all aspects of the energy sector shall be the guiding principle, and good governance
in the energy sector will be strengthened to realise accountability, fairness and transparency to achieve
investor and consumer confidence.

relations.Subject: corridors
relations.Description:
Available corridors will be used to lay multiple pipelines and power transmission lines wherever
possible.

relations.Subject: infrastructure
relations.Description:
3.9.5 All existing and future underground utility infrastructure including electricity, water, communication,
town gas and petroleum would be made available in a common mandatory geographic information
system (GIS) to facilitate optimal location of future underground cable routes and pipe transport
traces.

relations.Subject: chapter
relations.Description:
This chapter describes the targets and likely timeframes associated with expected policy intents
and the assignment of responsibilities of realisation of policy intents.

relations.Subject: player
relations.Description:
Every player in the petroleum subsector and all grid connected thermal power
plants shall jointly maintain a strategic fuel reserve equivalent to a minimum 30
days’ consumption at any given time.

relations.Subject: specifications
relations.Description:
All future power plant specifications
must contain appropriate storage capacities to be maintained locally.

relations.Subject: committee
relations.Description:
A high-level standing committee to be titled as ‘Energy Sector Risk Assessment
Panel’to be established with sufficient representation from key sectors by end2019to assess possible internal and external contingencies that could critically
affect the performance of the energy sector.

relations.Subject: Members
relations.Description:
Members of this committee must
also include co-opted specialists on the subject of risk assessment and be given
the required training on how to identify such risks.

relations.Subject: panel
relations.Description:
This panel must meet
periodically and identify such contingencies based on probability-impact analysis
and advise sector agencies to prepare plans to mitigate impacts of the same.

relations.Subject: 2a
relations.Description:
To ensure access to reliable, convenient, affordable, equitable and quality energy services
to all citizens to enhance their living standards and to engage in gainful economic
activities, the following targets and milestones will be met by institutions to which
responsibilities are assigned;
2a To encourage prospective small and medium scale industries and businesses, the
initial cost of obtaining an electricity connection, which may be considerable at
present compared with the capital cost of the business, will be reduced by offering
a special concessionary package under which the entire cost of the transformer
for contract demands up to 100kVA will be waived-off and be socialised through distribution tariffs.

relations.Subject: SEA
relations.Description:
SEA shall ensure a minimum 5% penetration of improved
stoves using commercialised biomass fuels by 2021.

relations.Subject: networks
relations.Description:
All new low voltage distribution networks will use all-insulated ABC with
immediate effect.

relations.Subject: targets
relations.Description:
The following targets and milestones will have
to be met by the institutions to which responsibilities are assigned.

relations.Subject: fuels
relations.Description:
Processed, commercialized biomassbased fuels used in such stoves will be made widely available across the retail
market by creating an enabling environment.

4d ‘Energy Manager’ scheme will be implemented on a mandatory basis by end 2019to
designated users and extended to the remaining institutional users by 2020.

relations.Subject: duty
relations.Description:
4e Reduced duty and taxation of efficient equipment supported by an accelerated
depreciation scheme will be offered to building renovation and retrofitting
industry to improve the energy efficiency of the existing building stock by 2020.

relations.Subject: services
relations.Description:
All routine services offered at government agencies that do not require physical
presence must be made available via internet or mobile phone to minimize transport
energy use from 2020.

relations.Subject: Incorporation
relations.Description:
4p Incorporation of building management systems with a focus on energy management
and future opportunities in smart grid driven automated demand response will be
made a mandatory planning criterion for all commercial developments by 2020by
the UDA.

At least 20% of all new light vehicle registrations shall be electric vehicles in
2022.

relations.Subject: SEA
relations.Description:
SEA will encourage the private sector to set up their own charging
stations to complement the CEB/LECO efforts, by securing fiscal incentives to
the industry.

relations.Subject: Applications
relations.Description:
7d Applications received by the SEA when feed-in tariffs were on
offer, but held up due to the termination to feed in tariffs, which
are at various stages of the approval process will be channeled
to a competitive bidding model by using suitable interim
approaches such as offering project proponents preferential
treatments when they were opened up for
competition considering the maturity of a project, investments
made, etc.

relations.Subject: package
relations.Description:
A premium green tariff/green energy certification package will be offered to all
interested electricity customer segments as an optional tariff and a portion of
incremental proceeds will be used for renewable energydevelopment by crediting
to the Sri Lanka Sustainable Energy Fund.

relations.Subject: 8b
relations.Description:
8b Establish a regulatory framework and empower an independent regulatory
institution by enacting the necessary legislation to regulate downstream petroleum
industry, by end-2020.

relations.Subject: 8i
relations.Description:
8i Establish clear guidelines to implement public-private partnership in developing
energy infrastructure, by mid-2020.

relations.Subject: 9e
relations.Description:
9e An inter-agency utility corridor coordination authority to resolve
conflicts will be established by2020.

relations.Subject: 10a
relations.Description:
10a A 25% local preference will be granted to Sri Lankan enterprises
and joint ventures led by such enterprises to encourage such
enterprises to engage in energy sector infrastructure
development,from2019.

The country 
has recently discovered oil and gas.

relations.Subject: government
relations.Description:
The 
government recognises the important role renewable energy will play in

relations.Subject: Both
relations.Description:
Both face intrinsic challenges, which cross all sectors and affect 
the whole population.

relations.Subject: use
relations.Description:
Current biomass 
use in Niger has major health implications, 
especially for women.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:
Niger has been importing electricity at a very low price, which 
has historically served as a disincentive to 
boosting its own generation capacity.

relations.Subject: Pool
relations.Description:
The West African Power Pool (WAPP) 
represents an opportunity for Niger.

relations.Subject: View

Off-grid renewable power can meet the

Niger, still in the early stages of building 
its energy infrastructure, has the opportunity to develop and invest in its energy

manner.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:
Niger possesses significant renewable 
energy resources to meet its present 
and future energy needs.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:
This dates back to the 1960s, 
when Niger set up the Solar Energy Office 
(Office de l’Energie Solaire – ONERSOL), 
later renamed the National Solar Energy 
Centre (Centre National d'Énergie Solaire 
– CNES).

This dates back to the 1960s, 
when Niger set up the Solar Energy Office 
(Office de l’Energie Solaire – ONERSOL), 
later renamed the National Solar Energy 
Centre (Centre National d'Énergie Solaire 
– CNES).

ONERSOL was founded to undertake applied renewable energy research, 
provide diagnostic studies on renewable 
energy technology use, and run training programmes on renewable energy 
systems.

relations.Subject: programme
relations.Description:
Yet this ambitious and promising 
programme did not achieve its intended 
goal of creating a strong renewable energy 
technical capability for the West African 
region.

relations.Subject: recognises
relations.Description:
It also 
recognises decentralised renewable energy 
options as a cost-effective alternative to 
grid expansion in many rural areas.

The government electrification strategy 
has embraced both grid-based and off-grid 
options, although the main policy focus still 
remains on the former.

relations.Subject: strategy
relations.Description:
The current 
strategy has set the objective of 10% 
renewables (excluding biomass) in the 
national energy mix by 2020.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This offers a real opportunity to integrate 
renewable energy into future plans and also 
strengthen Niger’s case for support from 
development partners.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This would, among 
other things, reduce technical, legal and 
administrative barriers while increasing 
private-sector confidence.

relations.Subject: law
relations.Description:
An overarching 
renewable energy law would create the 
right conditions.

relations.Subject: law
relations.Description:
Such a law should provide 
guaranteed access to the grid and priority 
dispatch of renewable electricity generation.

relations.Subject: development
relations.Description:
Furthermore, the development 
of a standardised, bankable PPA would 
greatly support the evolution of renewable energy auctioning.

relations.Subject: Partnership
relations.Description:
Niger’s Public-Private Partnership (PPP) 
office, which has expressed the desire to 
promote solar power investments, could 
be mandated by the renewable energy law 
to become the permitting and licensing 
authority for all renewable energy projects.

relations.Subject: law
relations.Description: The law could also enshrine a bankable

relations.Subject: model
relations.Description:
A model of this kind could open the door 
to self-producers and IPPs wishing to feed 
their electricity into the grid.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:
Niger has been using auctions to select IPPs 
to provide power to the grid at competitive prices.

relations.Subject: auctions
relations.Description:
Renewable energy 
auctions have already become a commonly 
used policy instrument in some countries.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:
Niger needs a comprehensive energy 
policy that puts the needs and demands 
of rural communities at centre stage and 
provides clear guidance on how to achieve 
progress on rural energy services.

The comprehensive policy 
would bring together local development 
plans and information on resources, finance 
and skills, facilitating the design of coordinated plans of action, sensitive to location.

relations.Subject: organisation
relations.Description:
The proposed organisation 
must also create enabling conditions for 
the private sector, ensure effective implementation, and maintain quality assurance.

relations.Subject: These
relations.Description:
These include equity, technology neutrality, high technical standards, 
poverty eradication and the protection 
of investor interests.

relations.Subject: Assessment
relations.Description:
Readiness Assessment (RRA) drew attention to the importance of raising domestic 
finance, as well to calibrate internal investment with wider development goals.

relations.Subject: this
relations.Description:
While this cannot be considered 
a long-term solution to the challenge of 
raising funding, it could provide energy 
for social development needs.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This would 
provide a dynamic data system, assembling data on the range of technologies 
and their performance under different 
conditions.

relations.Subject: mini
relations.Description:
The diesel based mini-grid 
operated by NIGELEC offers a compelling case for hybridisation with renewable 
energy sources.

relations.Subject: studies
relations.Description:
Detailed 
feasibility studies on hybridising the diesel

relations.Subject: panels
relations.Description:
However, 
cheap solar panels and components are 
entering the Nigerien market from neigh-bouring countries, with no institutionalised 
quality assurance and standard schemes.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This does not help the reputation of these 
technologies, still in their early stages, 
when systems break down.

relations.Subject: CNES
relations.Description:
As part of the industry’s revitalisation, 
CNES could play an important role in 
supporting the development of renewable 
energy technology standards and certification schemes for installers.

relations.Subject: kind
relations.Description:
this kind would have the additional benefit 
of creating new skilled jobs throughout 
the value chain, from small distributors to 
installers, maintainers and end-users.

relations.Subject: sector
relations.Description:
In various parts of the world, the biogas 
sector has delivered excellent results and 
supported rural development.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:
Niger has 
significant potential for biogas, and feasibility studies in the biogas sector have 
been conclusive.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This would 
contribute to the well-being of the country’s population while reducing pressure on 
natural resources.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:
Niger has a population of 
16 million with an annual growth rate of 3.3%.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This clearly demonstrates the Nigerien economy’s 
direct dependence on rainfall and water availability.

relations.Subject: emergence
relations.Description:
The emergence of oil on the 
Nigerien economic landscape has triggered new optimism concerning 
the country’s future development and balance of trade management.

Manufacturing 
has also increased its share to about 6% in 
2011, largely in the domain of food processing (AEO, 2013).

relations.Subject: states
relations.Description:
AfDB states that flows of Foreign Direct 
Investment (FDI) exceeded USD 1 billion 
(bn) in 2011 and remained high in 2012 at 
about USD 830m.

This 
makes the average Nigerien citizen among 
the lowest consumers of electricity in the 
world.

Moreover, about 76% of the population does not have access to electricity, 
much of which is restricted to urban areas.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This indicates significant pent-up demand 
in the power sector and a need to close the 
gap between demand and availability.

This 
signifies a limited use of energy in the 
productive sector.

relations.Subject: Households
relations.Description:
Households across Niger 
rely heavily on traditional biomass to meet 
their basic energy needs.

relations.Subject: strategies
relations.Description:
Several strategies such as Programme 
National de Reference d’Acces aux Services 
Energétiques –

relations.Subject: Programme
relations.Description:
PRASE - National Reference 
Programme on Access to Energy Services, 
have outlined the important role of renewable energy in delivering energy services.

Over the past five years this programme

decentralised solar systems for a wide 
range of end uses by about 1 MW.

relations.Subject: country
relations.Description:
The country still has some way to go in addressing a number of social development problems in education, health 
and water services.

relations.Subject: intervention
relations.Description:
Indeed, in many of these successful 
cases elsewhere, energy intervention in the 
social and economic sectors namely health, 
water, agriculture and education was made 
as part of a comprehensive development 
strategy.

relations.Subject: subgroups
relations.Description:
The subgroups reviewed the tentative list 
resource-service pairs suggested by MoEP 
after discussions with the national consultant to be further analysed and discussed.

relations.Description:
A 
national workshop held in September 2012 
prioritised five manageable short-

Resolving these will create good synergies and have a positive cumulative effect 
on the country’s readiness to scale up RE 
deployment.

relations.Description:

the region faces the difficulty of raising sufficient funds internally or

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:

relations.Subject: nature

79% of total consumption and meets 83%

relations.Description:

relations.Subject: which

The share of renewables

countries have limited industrialisation.

relations.Description:
However, since

relations.Description:

perimeter, entrusted to NCPC, has proven

relations.Description:

once the refinery reaches its maximum

Conditions in Niger for

Furthermore,

relations.Description:

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:
Niger does not generate sufficient electricity to meet the growing need for power 
from its population of 16 million.

relations.Subject: rate
relations.Description:
The preferential rate of electricity from Nigeria at USD 0.04/kWh partly 
explains this continued trend.

relations.Subject: reliance
relations.Description:
The heavy reliance 
on Nigeria for electricity can potentially 
undermine the resilience of Niger’s energy 
system, as in 2008 and 2010.

relations.Subject: supplies
relations.Description:
Erratic power 
supplies from Nigeria prompted Niger’s 
government to gradually reduce its reliance 
on Nigeria by purchasing new diesel-powered generators.

relations.Subject: supply
relations.Description:
Electricity supply in Niger also faces 
frequent blackouts due to limited power 
infrastructure.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This has 
prompted 20% of Nigerien firms to acquire 
their own generators (World Bank, 2010).

relations.Subject: number
relations.Description:
A growing number of urban households 
are also purchasing their own gensets as a 
backup power source.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:
As part 
of this endeavour, Niger is actively pursuing wholesale power generation and transmission improvement projects.

relations.Subject: These
relations.Description:
These will 
develop its own domestic power sources, 
particularly hydropower, other renewables 
and the oil and gas sector (Table 2).

relations.Subject: terms
relations.Description:
The terms of 
the code paved the way for IPPs, breaking

for electricity generation, transmission 
and distribution since its establishment.

relations.Subject: consultation
relations.Description:
Intensive 
stakeholder consultation is taking place 
with participation from key representatives 
from government, business and civil society to feed into the strategy.

relations.Description:
The tariff set depends on 
a number of factors, such as the electricity

criteria.

relations.Subject: utility
relations.Description:
The utility purchases tax-free domestically-produced diesel directly from the refinery at 
USD 0.70 per litre.

relations.Subject: country
relations.Description:
The country does not 
currently export crude oil.

relations.Subject: there
relations.Description:
It is 
important to note that Niger will continue 
to remain dependent on cheap electricity 
from Nigeria unless there is a price review.

Furthermore, in 2012 the government 
accepted the creation of a social tariff 
as part its energy access improvement 
efforts.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This supports low income and 
low consumption subscribers.

relations.Subject: category
relations.Description:
This category of households (3 kWh) is charged 
USD 0.11/kWh for the first 50 kWh 
consumed.

relations.Subject: tariffs
relations.Description:
These tariffs are 
fixed at USD 0.11/kWh and USD 0.07/kWh respectively.

relations.Subject: consumers
relations.Description:
However, at USD 0.158/kWh,

USD 0.07/kWh more than citizens in the 
average African country that rely heavily 
on thermal power systems (Eberhard, et

Niger 
needs substantial investments in system

relations.Description:
A parallel strategy will be important to

that use little energy.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description: Niger has considerable conventional and renewable energy resource potential.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This can play a major role in reducing dependency on imported power and 
increasing access to energy services.

relations.Subject: solutions
relations.Description:
The 
practical solutions may appear obvious, 
but Niger will need to develop the policy 
framework and incentives to accommodate 
new business models and new domestic 
and external energy investment.

relations.Subject: sector
relations.Description:
The energy sector in Niger faces some 
formidable challenges and new opportunities.

relations.Subject: constraints
relations.Description:
Its resource constraints in the energy 
sector have undermined economic and 
social development goals.

relations.Subject: communities
relations.Description: Rural communities face a particular challenge.

relations.Subject: remoteness
relations.Description:
Widespread 
poverty, low incomes, limited scope for 
moving beyond subsistence activities and 
the inherent disadvantage of the grid’s 
remoteness create structural obstacles 
to rural development.

relations.Subject: potential
relations.Description:
Niger’s untapped 
renewable energy potential provides 
opportunities for transforming urban and 
rural livelihoods.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description: Given its geographic and climatic conditions, Niger could develop a diverse portfolio of renewable energy technologies.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:
Niger has an excellent renewable energy 
resource profile.

relations.Subject: project
relations.Description:
This high 
profile dam project will generate hydropower and regulate the flow of the 
river Niger, retaining water during the dry season and supporting irrigation 
initiatives downstream.

relations.Subject: These
relations.Description:
These will not require 
dams and will be quicker to install.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:
Niger enjoys high solar radiation conditions 
in all eight of its regions.

relations.Subject: there
relations.Description:
Although solar radiation 
levels are high in all four meteorological 
stations, there appears higher variability 
over the year in cities of Arlit and Agadez 
located in the northern and central regions 
respectively.

relations.Subject: Niamey
relations.Description:
Niamey and Zinder, located at 
lower latitudes, show less variability across 
the year, hence making them excellent 
locations for harnessing solar energy.

relations.Subject: applications
relations.Description:
Solar energy applications in use in Niger at 
present include PV for mini-grid and standalone applications, solar crop dryers and 
solar water heating for homes and community applications.

relations.Subject: policies
relations.Description:
There are a few private sector players such 
as SunTotal and YASMA who dominate 
the national market, while policies have 
yet to excite wider commercial interest.

relations.Subject: by
relations.Description:
It is also partly constrained by taxes of 
over 52% (import tariffs and VAT), a lack of 
regulation on poor quality products smuggled from neighbouring countries, and 
the absence of a meaningful government 
renewables stimulus.

relations.Subject: cost
relations.Description:
There is growing investment interest in 
PV grid connection as the falling cost of 
PV in recent years brings the technology 
closer to grid parity in many parts of the 
world.

relations.Subject: government
relations.Description:
The 
government of Niger is negotiating a PPA 
for a 20 MW solar plant with a French 
company.

relations.Subject: project
relations.Description:
However, this project is facing 
opposition due to the proposed price of 
USD 0.165/kWh, which is significantly 
higher than imports from Nigeria but lower 
than the utility domestic generation costs.

relations.Subject: studies
relations.Description:
However, 
further studies may identify favourable 
sites in the more populated parts of the 
south and southeast.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:
Niger lacks adequate information on forest 
cover and biomass potential.

relations.Subject: Estimates
relations.Description:
Estimates by the Food and Agriculture 
Organisation (FAO), however, indicate a

or about 2% of the country’s land area.

relations.Subject: pace
relations.Description:
The pace of wood harvesting 
has long exceeded the replenishment rate.

relations.Subject: trend
relations.Description:
This trend 
shows a steady decrease in supply to meet 
a growing demand for wood energy.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This sometimes harms 
soil fertility as bio resources are diverted

needs.

relations.Subject: Digesters
relations.Description:
Digesters require a 
large amount of water, which may limit the

other Sahelian countries.

relations.Subject: sector
relations.Description:
The energy sector in Niger contains a multitude of stakeholders, which 
include government bodies and parastatal organisations, NGOs and associations as well as the private sector.

relations.Subject: Some
relations.Description:
Some of these play multiple roles in 
policy, regulation, finance, knowledge generation and advocacy.

relations.Description:

below.

While IPPs are allowed to generate power, NIGELEC 
has a monopoly over power distribution across the country.

relations.Subject: Niger
relations.Description:
Niger, carries out applied research on wind 
energy, biogas and biofuels.

relations.Subject: Company
relations.Description:
Araren Coal Company, created in 1978, 
produces electricity from coal and distributes it to northern Niger.

relations.Description:
Agence Nationale de Financement des 
Collectivités Territoriales – ANFICT, the 
National Agency for Financing National 
Collectives, manages two funds.

These 
include the fund supporting decentralisation and the equalisation fund, which 
welcomes development partner contributions to financing local authority 
investments.

relations.Subject: strategies
relations.Description:
National 
strategies on domestic and renewable

promotion, and potential hydropower

process (MME, 2004b).

relations.Subject: policy
relations.Description:
The policy has been a major step towards

systems.

relations.Subject: terms
relations.Description:
The terms of the code created the 
conditions for IPPs to play a role in the 
future development of the power sector.

relations.Subject: IPPs
relations.Description:
The terms of the code created the 
conditions for IPPs to play a role in the 
future development of the power sector.

relations.Description:
Three energy strategies followed up the 
energy policy.

and SONICHAR, self-generators such as

Although the generation sector has been open to the private

relations.Description:
The Energy 
Fund consists of monies collected through

product sold at the pump.

relations.Subject: draft
relations.Description:

portion of revenues generated by mineral 
resource exploitation into the country’s

relations.Subject: code
relations.Description:

legal protection to private investors in 
energy production involved in promoting programmes contributing to the social 
and economic development of the country.

relations.Description:

privileged regimes and advantages in the

Category A (also known as the promotional category) is for investments of 
USD 100,000-200,000.

relations.Subject: Investors
relations.Description:

from the same advantages as the previous 
category.

relations.Subject: grid
relations.Description:
The grid remains an important means for reaching large 
numbers of people cost-effectively, and extending the grid is by far 
the most common way to provide power to communities.

relations.Subject: grid
relations.Description:
In Niger, the 
grid offers a significant opportunity to broaden access to electricity, 
though formidable technical, institutional, resource and financial barriers remain.

relations.Subject: This

This limits growth in critical 
productive sectors such as agro-processing and other small-scale industries.

relations.Subject: deployment

energy supply and build a stable and resilient power infrastructure.

relations.Description:

section considers grid-based wind and PV technologies for Niger.

relations.Subject: PV
relations.Description:
In recent years, the cost of PV systems has fallen sharply, 
making it possible for grid-based PV to achieve grid parity.

relations.Subject: countries
relations.Description:
It is, 
therefore, fast becoming a genuine alternative for countries to meet 
their energy access goals and cushion their economies from volatile fossil fuel prices.

relations.Subject: there
relations.Description:
While there is considerable experience 
of PV systems in Niger, much of it is offgrid.

relations.Subject: analysis
relations.Description:

as part of the pre-feasibility study of a 
20 MW grid-connected solar PV system 
near Niamey under negotiation at present.

relations.Subject: analysis
relations.Description:
The analysis demonstrated a number of 
important features of PV grid systems in 
Niger.

relations.Subject: cost
relations.Description:
However, as the 
cost of PV systems continues to fall, their 
value as a reliable and cost-effective power 
generation option increases, particularly 
for periods of peak electricity demand 
during the day.

relations.Subject: systems
relations.Description:

potential investors;

accordance to enforced norms and 
standards.

technical standards, poverty eradication 
and the protection of investor interests.

relations.Subject: Albania
relations.Description:
Albania faces multiple challenges that drive vulnerabilities, including weaknesses in 
rule of law, uneven institutional capacity, service gaps, limited investments in social services,
degradation of natural resources and few labour opportunities.

relations.Subject: disease
relations.Description:
The November 2019 earthquake and coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic
highlighted the need to address disaster risk management and the socioeconomic impact of 
these events, particularly on vulnerable groups and micro, small and medium-sized
enterprises.

relations.Subject: The
relations.Description:
The pandemic deepened gender inequalities, disproportionately affecting 
women, their livelihoods and access to essential health services, and increased incidents of 
gender-based violence.

relations.Subject: Union
relations.Description: In March 2020, the European Union opened accession negotiations.

relations.Subject: programme
relations.Description:
This country programme reflects the comparative advantages of UNDP in supporting 
national reforms and upholding values of justice, human rights, equity and gender equality,
through coordinated multisectoral approaches that facilitate systemic reforms.

relations.Subject: Those
relations.Description:
Those left behind include women, children from low-income households, single parent 
households, persons with disabilities, the Roma and Egyptian communities, refugees, 
migrants, isolated rural communities, the elderly and bisexual, transgender, queer and 
intersex persons.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Through a portfolio approach, UNDP will target these 
groups and increase social cohesion and social protection, in partnership with national and 
local governments, United Nations agencies and civil society.

relations.Subject: offer
relations.Description:
The UNDP integration offer includes innovation, thematic expertise and financing for
renewables and energy efficiency in line with Government’s plans to provide safe, affordable 
and clean energy to citizens; and for raising the national ambitions to combat climate change 
and increase resilience to natural and human-induced risks.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will promote nature-based 
solutions to climate change adaptation and mitigation, not only tackling the climate crisis, 
inequality, poverty and food insecurity, but also providing incentives for new jobs in the 
maritime, blue and eco-circular economies.

Partnering with United Nations agencies, UNDP 
will implement programmes on a green circular economy and sustainable economic 
development.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
To the 
extent possible, UNDP will promote South-South and triangular cooperation in support of 
these efforts.

relations.Subject: report
relations.Description:
The report of the United Nations mainstreaming, acceleration and policy support 
mission to Albania and the United Nations country team reached consensus on three highly 
effective solutions for policy and programming to accelerate progress towards European 
Union accession and achieve the Sustainable Development Goals: (a) human capital 
development and social inclusion; (b) sustainable, resilient and green economic growth and 
resource management; (c) effective, people-centred governance, human rights, rule of law 
and gender equality.

relations.Subject: programme
relations.Description:
This country programme reflects the country’s development priorities as articulated in 
the NSDI and the UNSDCF 2022-2026.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Specifically, 
UNDP will assist the country in the three main areas described below.

relations.Subject: Albania
relations.Description:
Albania needs well-functioning,
fully operational and funded social inclusion and protection policies.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
With United Nations agencies, UNDP will ensure civic engagement and capacities for 
dialogue and implementation of social care plans.

relations.Subject: COVID-19
relations.Description:
17. COVID-19 generated a sense of urgency to operationalize national policies, strengthen 
local government capacities and design and fund inclusive, gender-responsive and evidencebased services.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
To reach those most left behind, UNDP will expand services at municipal 
and national levels in education, health, social care, employment, vocational training and 
housing.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP, with the European Union, will continue investments in the education sector
affected by the 2019 earthquake, adopting European Union standards and expanding 
information and communication technology measures as a post-COVID-19 recovery 
strategy.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will technically lead implementation of the United Nations COVID-19 
socioeconomic recovery plan.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support policies that accelerate an inclusive, productive and sustainable 
economy, enhance climate resilience and adaptation planning, and transition into a clean 
green economy, in line with the Government’s national strategies.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support industries to become more energy-efficient,
increase the potential of the forestry sector for removal of greenhouse gasses, and support 
the country’s green growth trajectory.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support promotion of nature-based tourism 
that sustains livelihoods and protected areas, while improving ecosystem services and 
financial sustainability.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support entities to have improved systems and capacities to design and 
implement innovative policies, particularly in relation to qualitative skills development that 
promotes a digital economy, entrepreneurship and competitive green businesses.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will consolidate reforms, strengthen capacities, address skills mismatch and increase 
labour force participation especially for women and young people, persons with disabilities, 
Roma and Egyptian communities and the long-term unemployed.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
To contribute to a strengthened risk and disaster management system, UNDP will assist 
the Government in driving policies and actions that focus on prevention and reduction of 
disaster-related risks, increasing resilience of infrastructures, ecosystems and society, and 
enabling adaptive capacities, all as a means to reduce the long-term vulnerability of the 
population and protect development investments, particularly in at-risk areas.

relations.Subject: strategies
relations.Description:
Raising the national 
ambition to combat climate change, increasing resilience to natural and human-induced risk, 
and gender-responsive disaster strategies remain priorities.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will broaden partnerships for a stronger good governance framework, in 
line with the National Public Administration Reform Strategy.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will foster a citizencentred, gender-sensitive, inclusive approach, while further developing institutional
capacities in policymaking and implementation, promoting a culture of participation and 
dialogue for development, and increasing transparency, integrity and accountability.

Based 
on its initial successful experiences in rolling out integrity planning in municipalities, UNDP 
will build national capacities to bring to scale and monitor this initiative.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support integrated citizen-centred services and further 
expand municipal one-stop-shop networks to reach remote, mostly rural areas.

relations.Subject: programme
relations.Description:
The programme will support data availability and a more data-driven culture for
strengthened sectoral analysis, evidence-based policymaking and promotion of a culture of 
accountability and performance assessment.

relations.Subject: analysis
relations.Description:
Policy analysis and formulation will include a 
gender equality focus and gender-disaggregated data.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will engage gender champions 
and support increased civic engagement and dialogue platforms.

relations.Subject: document
relations.Description:
This country programme document (CPD) outlines UNDP’s contributions to national 
results and serves as the primary unit of accountability to the Executive Board for results 
alignment and resources assigned to the programme at country level.

relations.Subject: changes
relations.Description:
Possible changes in the process and requirements for European Union accession may impact 
national development policies.

relations.Subject: hazards
relations.Description:
Natural or man-made hazards, with insufficient institutional 
and local preparedness to respond, can impact the ability of UNDP to support Albania in 
delivering its development priorities.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This demonstrates a clear linkage between the support 
provided by UNDP, the programme outcomes and sustainable development results.

relations.Subject: practices
relations.Description:
Ethical practices and lessons 
learned shape policy advice, advocacy and project design and implementation.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will employ national monitoring systems, official statistical data and reports 
from line ministries, development partners and research institutions to measure its 
contribution to national results.

relations.Subject: Office
relations.Description:
The National Statistical Office and other partners will 
receive support to continue improving data quality.

relations.Subject: programme
relations.Description:
The 
programme will reinforce innovative tools to manage data collection and analysis at the 
country programme outcome and output levels.

relations.Description: Both these subsectors, which are largely served by state-owned utilities, are presently undergoing process of reforms.

relations.Subject: PUCSL
relations.Description:
Although the PUCSL has been already set up under the provisions of the Public Utilities Commission of
Sri Lanka Act No. 35 of 2002 to regulate the physical infrastructure sectors, it will be empowered to execute regulation only
when the individual industry legislations are enacted and made effective.

relations.Subject: player
relations.Description:
A third
player could also join petroleum distribution, but this has been temporarily suspended by the Government due to the lack of
anticipated benefits to the country and its consumers through the liberalization and part privatization of the downstream
petroleum sub-sector.

relations.Subject: PUCSL
relations.Description:
PUCSL, which will be the future petroleum sub-sector regulator, will have the authority to decide on the
future structure of the petroleum sub sector.

relations.Subject: Biomass
relations.Description: Biomass still remains a sub-sector not formally organised unlike the electricity and petroleum sub-sectors.

relations.Subject: Strategies
relations.Description: * “Implementing Strategies” states the implementation framework to achieve each policy element.

relations.Subject: utilisation
relations.Description:
Efficient utilisation of energy by all concerned, from utilities (supply-side management) to final
consumers (demand-side management) not only saves valuable resources of the country but also reduces the
overall cost of energy to the consumer.

relations.Subject: dependence
relations.Description:
Minimum dependence on non-indigenous resources and optimum development of local energy resources will
minimise the vulnerability of energy supplies to external factors such as the international socio-political
environment.

relations.Subject: Policy
relations.Description:
The Energy Policy includes
necessary initiatives to vigorously implement the country’s oil and gas exploration programme.

relations.Subject: subsidies
relations.Description:
Non-cost reflective pricing and non-targeted subsidies both in the electricity and petroleum sub-sectors in the
absence of a property regulatory mechanism, seriously hamper the growth and financial viability of sub-sector
utilities.

relations.Subject: quality
relations.Description:
Poor quality of energy services affects the country’s economic growth and the general standard of living of the
public.

relations.Subject: impacts
relations.Description:
Adverse impacts on society and the environment arising out of the electricity and petroleum sub-sector
activities have not been receiving adequate attention.

relations.Subject: developments
relations.Description:
All developments and operations of energy sector facilities shall follow the relevant environmental regulations
and standards of Sri Lanka.

relations.Subject: Priority
relations.Description:
3.1 Providing Basic Energy Needs
* Priority will be given to improving access by rural areas to commercial energy forms such as electricity and
petroleum-based fuels.

relations.Subject: transportation
relations.Description:
Railway transportation will receive priority over road
transportation.

relations.Subject: country
relations.Description:
* A strategic plan for street lighting will be formulated for the country to ensure proper management of street
lighting which will enhance the safety of motorists and pedestrians and also contribute to energy conservation
with better aesthetic sense.

relations.Subject: Initiatives
relations.Description:
* Initiatives of other sectors and institutions to convert biomass and other waste to energy will be encouraged
and supported where appropriate.

relations.Subject: prices
relations.Description:
These prices will include elements such as a reasonable return on equity,
internal cash generation for capital investment and debt service.

relations.Subject: utility
relations.Description:
Every energy sector utility will establish an environmental division with staff qualified to conduct
environmental safety audits of existing and new facilities to comply with the standards and regulations under
the National Environment Act.

relations.Subject: measures
relations.Description:
* Necessary measures will be taken to establish appropriate market structures within electricity and petroleum
sub-sectors by attracting investments from public and private sectors.

relations.Subject: Electrification
relations.Description:
4.1 Electrification of Households
Electricity will be made available to all feasible areas by extending the national grid and focussed rural energy
initiatives using off-grid technologies.

relations.Subject: studies
relations.Description:
The LTGEP studies confirm the viability of this
strategy.

relations.Subject: Energy
relations.Description:
Non-conventional Renewable Energy (NRE) shall be the fourth resource in this deversification and
security strategy.

relations.Subject: player
relations.Description:
Every player in the petroleum sub-sector downstream retail business shall maintain a strategic fuel reserve
equivalent to a minimumof 30 days’ consumption at any given time.

The Long-Term Generation Expansion Plan
(LTGEP) shall reflect the above strategy and milestones.

relations.Subject: LTGEP
relations.Description:
LTGEP shall be a 20-year plan, updated at least once in two
years.

relations.Subject: Electricity
relations.Description:
Based Electricity in the Grid
* NRE Resources include small-scale hydropower, biomass including dendro power, biogas and waste, solar
power and wind power.

relations.Subject: Government
relations.Description:
If justified, the
Government may subsidize the energy utilities for this purpose.

relations.Subject: Government
relations.Description:
* To make available the incentives for NRE technologies, the Government will create an ‘Energy Fund’ ,which will
be managed by the ECF.

relations.Subject: developments
relations.Description:
* NRE developments will not be charged any resource cost(royalty) for a period of 15 years from the commercial
operation date.

relations.Subject: ECF
relations.Description:
The ECF shall prepare a Long-term Non-conventional Renewable Energy Plan (LTNREP), which shall provide interim
targets for specific NRE technologies, upper thresholds of pricing, and resource costing.

relations.Subject: LTNREP
relations.Description:
The LTNREP shall be a 20 year
plan, updated at least once in two years.

relations.Subject: price
relations.Description: * Average electricity price to each category of consumers will be gradually made cost reflective.

relations.Subject: tariff
relations.Description:
The lifeline tariff to domestic consumers will be limited to Samurdhi Beneficiaries and to a monthly household
consumption of 30kWh.

relations.Subject: Consumers
relations.Description:
Consumers and all other stake holders will be given opportunities to present their views at
a public hearing.

relations.Subject: utilities
relations.Description:
Electricty distribution utilities shall prepare tariff proposals for the approval of PUCSL, which will seek
concurrence of the Treasury on Government subsidy.

relations.Subject: subsidy
relations.Description:
No general subsidy will be provided to any of the
products and the marketing companies will be allowed to decide on their retail consumer prices within the specified maximum
retail consumer prices for the period.

relations.Subject: wille
relations.Description: Targeted subsidies wille be made available to low income

relations.Subject: distributors
relations.Description:
Petroleum
distributors shall prepare the product pricing proposals according to the agreed formula for the approval of the PUCSL
which will seek concurrence of the Treasury on the Government subsidy.

relations.Subject: location
relations.Description:
The Strategic geographical location of Sri Lanka places it in a very favourable situation to become a leader in the
bunkering business in South Asia.

The appliance labelling programme
will be made mandatory to identified appliances by mid 2007.

relations.Subject: variety
relations.Description:
* A variety of financing mechanisms will be made available by end 2007 to finance energy efficiency improvement
projects in all sectors including collateral substitution to concessionary loans, operated through utilities.

relations.Subject: Responsibility
relations.Description:
Institutional Responsibility to implement these strategies to reach the targets specified lies with the ECF, and shall be
assisated by electricity and petroleum utilities, the PUCSL and other stakholders.

relations.Subject: Ministry
relations.Description:
* Ministry of Power and Energy shall immediately establish a national energy palnning team, to address the
policy issues inter-linkages between sub-sectors, and to investigate important issues such as pricing policy
in consultation with public, private and civil society groups.

relations.Subject: team
relations.Description:
* The planning team shall, by end of 2007 establish improved methodology, if necessary, to develop demand
forecasts, simulate development scenarios, intergrate sub-sectoral plans, conduct sensitivity studies, analyse
policy options, and develop forecast energy balances.

relations.Subject: government
relations.Description:
In this
context, the government will study the policies/programs adopted by other developing countries.

relations.Subject: government
relations.Description:
The government will also
seriously consider entrusting the management of RE schemes to consumer co-operatives, a policy successfully implemented
by some developing countries.

relations.Subject: Responsibility
relations.Description:
Institutional Responsibility to implement this lies with the Ministry of Power and Energy and the Ministry of Finance,
assisted by the PUCSL.

relations.Subject: country
relations.Description:
The country has undergone considerable economic reform 
since independence to develop an open economy and is about to open accession negotiations 
with the European Union.

relations.Subject: independence
relations.Description:
The country has undergone considerable economic reform 
since independence to develop an open economy and is about to open accession negotiations 
with the European Union.

relations.Subject: migration
relations.Description:
Out-migration and mismatch between education and market 
needs create labour-force challenges.

relations.Subject: policies
relations.Description:
Sectoral policies and plans emphasize dynamic and 
inclusive economic growth, high-quality health care, education and social protection, 
improved governance, environmental protection and disaster risk reduction.

relations.Subject: results
relations.Description:
Expected results address system weaknesses existing prior to the pandemic and 
promote accelerators to recover better, including investments in innovation, digitization, and 
public-sector and community resilience to prepare for future shocks.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will engage in United Nations
joint programmes for integrated service provision, disability, climate change, air pollution, 
youth, and gender equality.

relations.Subject: comprises
relations.Description:
The UNDP integrator role in North Macedonia comprises thought leadership, a platform 
approach, and programmatic focus on innovation and resilience.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will apply modern data and analytics to join social, economic 
and environmental analysis to integrated approaches and developing scenarios that address 
complex development problems, such as COVID-19 recovery, air pollution, corruption, and 
out-migration.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will convene multiple stakeholders – including start-ups, 
accelerators, international financial institutions and domestic banks – to develop sustainable 
solutions for national challenges.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will scale up programme innovations, including the Skopje Lab, the 
Innovation Hub, and platforms for disaster risk management and small and medium-sized
enterprises.

relations.Subject: Lab
relations.Description:
An Acceleration Lab – part of the global network – will offer world-class 
expertise to addressing emerging policy areas such as the green, circular economy and the 
care economy.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will test new solutions to help businesses navigate the COVID-19 
economy and will inform government policies for creating sustainable, formal and green jobs.

relations.Subject: Macedonia
relations.Description:
North Macedonia has made progress towards a market economy with greater trade 
openness and private-sector development.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This constitutes a major loss of 
productivity and jeopardizes the economic future.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will engage public and private stakeholders to invest in the business ecosystem 
with a focus on entrepreneurship, enhanced value chains, and trade.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support 
businesses in navigating the economy as it recovers from the pandemic, including digital 
transformation.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
the previous programme, UNDP demonstrated its effectiveness by supporting the creation of 
over 13,000 formal sector jobs and 12,000 new small businesses, accounting for 12 per cent
of new companies registered during the period, and 10 new social services serving vulnerable 
groups.

relations.Subject: analysis
relations.Description:
The common country analysis highlights significant climate change risks: land 
degradation, food insecurity, floods, biodiversity loss, and damage to public infrastructure.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This highlights the critical 
environment-health nexus and the need for affordable, clean energy.
