relations.Subject: تجدید
relations.Description: که پروژه هاي انرژي قابل تجدید در آنجا در مرحلۀ اول به گونه منظم روي دست گرفته خواهد شد.

relations.Subject: قابل
relations.Description:
.2 این پالیسـی ترتیب نقشـه هاي تفصــیلی منابع انرژي هاي قابل تجدید را در سطح زون ها بمنظور ترتیب 
نقشه هاي انرژي قابل تجدید افغانستان و ترتیب ماستر پلان ها در سطح ولایات مورد حمایت قرار می دهد.

relations.Subject: ترتیب
relations.Description:
.2 این پالیسـی ترتیب نقشـه هاي تفصــیلی منابع انرژي هاي قابل تجدید را در سطح زون ها بمنظور ترتیب 
نقشه هاي انرژي قابل تجدید افغانستان و ترتیب ماستر پلان ها در سطح ولایات مورد حمایت قرار می دهد.

relations.Subject: رهبري
relations.Description:
.3 این پالیســی ساختار هاي رهبري غیرمتمرکز را که همآهنگی و سهولت هاي محلی را از طریق مراکز زون 
هاي انرژي قابل تجدید وزارت انرژي و آب فراهم میسازد، حمایت مینماید.

relations.Subject: وزارت
relations.Description:
.4 طبق این پالیسـی، وزارت احیا و انکشــاف دهات داراي صلاحیت تطبیق پروژه هاي انرژي قابل تجدید الی 
ظرفیت یک (1) میگاوات می باشد.

relations.Subject: از
relations.Description: را از طریق مشـوقات مالی و سایر انواع تسـهیلات از جمله انتقال

.6 طبق این پالیسـی تطبیق پروژه هاي انرژي قابل تجدید تحت 100 کیلووات که توسط سکتور خصــوصی، 
ارگان هاي دولتی وغیر دولتی یا افراد که پروژه را از طرف ســایر ادارات دولتی یا تمویل کننده تطبیق مینماید از 
اخذ جواز تولید انرژي مطابق قانون تنظیم خدمات انرژي برق مستثنی میباشد.

relations.Subject: تهداب
relations.Description:
.8 این پالیسی اساس و تهداب ایجاد "صندوق وجهی"را براي پروژه هاي انرژي قابل تجدید می گذارد که این 
صندوق بعداً به عنوان نهاد مشـخص مالی براي تمویل پروژه هاي انرژي قابل تجدید در مرحله دوم این پالیســی 
عرض اندام خواهد نمود.

relations.Subject: تقویت
relations.Description:
.9 این پالیسـی تقویت ساختاري و تشـکیلات مجدد ساختار ها را به شمول ایجاد نهاد هاي جدید تأکید می 
کند.

relations.Subject: نهاد
relations.Description:
.9 این پالیسـی تقویت ساختاري و تشـکیلات مجدد ساختار ها را به شمول ایجاد نهاد هاي جدید تأکید می 
کند.

relations.Subject: استفاده
relations.Description:
.10 این پالیسـی استفاده از معیار ها و کنترول کیفیت، نظارت و مدیریت آگاهی را حتمی و ضروري دانسـته و 
تولیدات محلی، آموزش و ارتقاي سطح آگاهی استفاده کنندگان را مورد حمایت قرار می دهد.

relations.Subject: ثبات
relations.Description:
.11 این پالیسـی بر ایجاد طرح هاي خرید برق، حفظ سرمایه گذاري، فروش برق، مارکیت بیمه، مشـوق هاي 
مالیاتی، مشــوق هاي مالی مانند کمک هاي بلا عوض، قرض هاي طویل مدت، قرضه ها، تخفیف و مشــوق هاي 
تولیداتی، تأکید میدارد.1.1 افغانســــــــــتان در آستانۀ ثبات و رشد قرار دارد و در این راستا به منابع مطمئن انرژي نیازمند بوده و 
خوشــبختانه از منابع انرژي قابل تجدید به شــمول انرژي آفتابی، بادي، آبی، بایومس و حرارت زمین برخوردار 
است. مطابق قانون تنظیم خدمات انرژي برق، دسترسی به انرژي برق با استفاده از هر نوع منابع انرژي کشــــور 
حق همه اسـت و تولیدات انرژي برق باید افزایش یابد، لهذا هدف رشـد انرژي قابل تجدید، رشـد ســکتور انرژي 
افغانستان میباشد.

relations.Subject: مطابقت
relations.Description:
2.1 این پالیسی در مطابقت و همخوانی با ماستر پلان سکتور انرژي برق و استراتیژي انکشاف ملی افغانسـتان 
قرار داشته تا چهارچوبرا براي انکشـاف و رشد انرژي قابل تجدید مشـخص سازد.

relations.Subject: پالیسـی
relations.Description:
از سوي دیگر، این پالیسـی در 
همخوانی با پالیسی ملی انرژي قابل تجدید قرار دارد تا از اجراء و تطبیق کامل رهنمود هاي پالیسی سکتور انرژي 
همه مناطق کشور اطمینان حاصل گردد.

relations.Subject: تجدید
relations.Description:
3.1 هدف این پالیسی گسـترش انرژي هاي قابل تجدید با ظرفیت 4500 الی 5000 میگاوات الی سال 2032 
است، که این مقدار در حدود 95 فیصــــــد از مجموع انرژي 5000 الی 6000 میگاوات است که در ماستر پلان 
سکتور برق پیشـبینی شده است.

relations.Subject: در
relations.Description:
این 
پالیسی در دو مرحله تطبیق خواهد گردید: مرحله اول: از سال 2015 الی 2020 میباشد، که حمایت

relations.Subject: ایجاد
relations.Description:
و ایجاد یک 
فضاي خوب براي فعالیت، رشد و پیشرفت انرژي هاي قابل تجدید و بالخصـوص شیوه هاي همکاري میان سکتور 
هاي عامه و خصوصی خواهد بود.

relations.Subject: در
relations.Description:
4.1 در مرحلۀ اول تطبیق این پالیسی کمیته همآهنگی انرژي قابل تجدید در چوکات وزارت انرژي و آب تحت 
نظر معینیت انرژي ایجاد میگردد، ارگان هاي دولتی و غیر دولتی ذیربط عضویت این کمیته را داشته و سکرتریت 
آنرا ریاسـت انرژي قابل تجدید وزارت انرژي و آب بعهده خواهد داشــت و همچنان این کمیته داراي گروپ هاي 
کاري تخنیکی متشکل از متخصصین ارگانهاي فوق الذکر خواهد بود.

relations.Subject: را
relations.Description:
24
13.0 بلندبردن مثمریت انرژي وحفاظت محیط زیست با انرژیهاي قابل تجدید.......................................... 25 
شماره عناوین صفحهع 
ج - این پالیســــــی سرمایه گذار را براي مطابق به قانون تنظیم خدمات انرژي برق، تولید انرژي برق از منابع انرژي قابل 
تجدید را در یک یا چند محل اجازه می دهد و ســرمایه گذار می تواند همان مقدار برق را در جاي دیگر از شــبکه به 
هزینه خود با درنظرداشت ضایعات انتقال برق و پرداخت پول سایر مصارف، استفاده نماید.

relations.Subject: فروش
relations.Description:
د- این پالیســی اجازه خرید و فروش برق را می دهد تا تولید کننده، برق اضافی خود را در یک زمان به فروش برساند و در 
زمان دیگر از برق شبکه استفاده نماید و تصـفیه حســاب خود را به اساس تفاهم خرید برق انجام دهد .

relations.Subject: این
relations.Description:
این نوع فعالیت 
اقتصادي تولید کنند گان کوچک و انفرادي را کمک می نماید و استفاده از ظرفیت سیسـتم هاي نصـب شده را تقویت 
می بخشد.

relations.Subject: انرژي
relations.Description:
ذ- این پالیسـی تولید انرژي برق را ازمنابع انرژي قابل تجدید که داراي ظرفیت کمتر از 100 کیلو وات باشند مطابق جزء 
سوم مادة هشـتم فصـل دوم قانون تنظیم خدمات انرژي برق، از گرفتن جواز مسـتثنا قرار میدهد تا مصـارف سرمایه 
گذاري براي چنین سرمایه گذاري کاهش داده شـود.

relations.Subject: اصول
relations.Description: ر - این پالیســی اصول ساده و شفاف را براي تعیین تعرفه، معرفی

relations.Subject: خطر
relations.Description:
می نماید و سرمایه گذار را از خطر تنوع در منابع که به 
خریدار برق اختصاص داده شده، محافظت می کند.

relations.Subject: به
relations.Description:
ز- این پالیســـی تســــهیلات لازم را براي پروژه ها جهت به دست آوردن سود از عدم تولید کاربن (کاربن کریدت) براي 
اجتناب از انتشار گازهاي گلخانه اي فراهم نموده، بهبود بازدهی مالی را کمک و قیمت خرید برق را کاهش میدهد.

relations.Subject: ممکن
relations.Description:
ش- این پالیسی ممکن است درآینده به اصلاح و تغییرات جزئی بر اساس تجارب، مشکلات فنی پروژه ها، پرداخت صرفیۀ 
برق، پیشنهادات و توصیه هاي سرمایه گذاران ، نیاز داشته باشد.

با اغتنام از فرصت از زحمات وسعی جدي ریاست طرح و تنظیم پالیســــی هاي انرژي که با درك مســــؤولیت هاي 
وظیفوي خویش با همکاري و حمایت مالی اداره محترم

relations.Subject: نهادهاي
relations.Description:
و نهادهاي سکتوري که در تسـوید این سند ملی نظریات، رهنماي، پشـتیبانی و همکاري خویش را 
دریغ نورزیده اند اظهار تشــــــکر نموده و از خداوند منان (ج ) مؤفقیت هاي مزید شان را در تمام عرصه هاي زند گی 
استدعا میدارم.

relations.Subject: مقایسه
relations.Description:
این منابع 
در مقایسه با منابع عنعنوي انرژي که بیشتر در یک مکان خاص متمرکز هسـتند ، طور گسـترده در سراسر کشـور موجود 
میباشد.

relations.Subject: اقلیم
relations.Description: و کاهش اثرات منفی تغیر اقلیم درسطح بین المللی می شود.

relations.Subject: همکاري
relations.Description:
دولت جمهوري افغانستان 
خواهان همکاري جامعۀ بین المللی براي رشد و ترویج انرژي قابل تجدید بوده که در بیســـــت سال آینده در حدود 95 
درصد تولید انرژي برق کشور از منابع انرژي قابل تجدید خواهد بود.

relations.Subject: انرژي
relations.Description: وزارت انرژي و آب به منظور تحقق دیدگاه و اهداف استراتیژیک دولت جمهوري

relations.Subject: قابل
relations.Description:
افغانستان و تطبیق قانون تنظیم 
خدمات انرژي برق، پالیســـــی انرژي قابل تجدید را تدوین نموده است که روند اصلی پروژه هاي انرژي قابل تجدید را در 
برنامه هاي توسعه وي کشور پیشبینی می نماید.

relations.Subject: قابل
relations.Description:
افغانستان و تطبیق قانون تنظیم 
خدمات انرژي برق، پالیســـــی انرژي قابل تجدید را تدوین نموده است که روند اصلی پروژه هاي انرژي قابل تجدید را در 
برنامه هاي توسعه وي کشور پیشبینی می نماید.

relations.Subject: پالیســی
relations.Description: این پالیســی در دو مرحله تطبیق خواهد گردید مرحلۀ اول ( – 2015 - 2020 ) محیط سالم را براي فعالیت هاي توسعه

relations.Subject: تجدید
relations.Description: وي و رشد سکتور انرژي قابل تجدید به خصوص مشارکت سکتورهاي عامه

relations.Subject: از
relations.Description:
برخی از ویژگی هاي برجستۀپالیسی انرژي قابل تجدید قرار ذیل میباشد:
الف - این پالیســی سرمایه گذاري در پروژه هاي انرژي قابل تجدید را براي سکتور خصـــوصی تحت کتگوري هاي طرح 
پیشنهادي ذیل قبول می نماید:

relations.Subject: قابل
relations.Description:
برخی از ویژگی هاي برجستۀپالیسی انرژي قابل تجدید قرار ذیل میباشد:
الف - این پالیســی سرمایه گذاري در پروژه هاي انرژي قابل تجدید را براي سکتور خصـــوصی تحت کتگوري هاي طرح 
پیشنهادي ذیل قبول می نماید:

relations.Subject: Afghanistan
relations.Description:
With presidential 
elections in 2014, the withdrawal of international troops, and the closure of 
provincial reconstruction teams, Afghanistan continues its journey towards selfreliance.

relations.Subject: Afghanistan
relations.Description:
As Afghanistan enters its Transformation Decade, UNDP 
should also transition to meet emerging priorities and operational challenges, guided 
by the United Nations Development Assistance Framework and the new strategic 
plan, 2014-2017.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Furthermore, UNDP is supporting the 
implementation of the New Deal for Engagement in Fragile States principle s with 
the Ministry of Finance.

relations.Subject: solutions
relations.Description:
For peacebuilding to succeed, 
moreover, development solutions must tackle the root causes of conflict and 
exclusion.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will follow an issues-based approach addressing some of the key 
links and the nexus between conflict and better governance, and between poverty 
and community resilience.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Yet UNDP achieved only limited results in increased 
opportunities for income generation, pointing to a need to intensify its work in the 
area of sustainable livelihoods for poverty reduction and, where possible, regional 
and triangular cooperation.

relations.Subject: assessment
relations.Description:
The 
assessment identified several causes of conflict and fragility.

relations.Subject: institutions
relations.Description:
Governance institutions need 
time to mature to enable state services to reach all citizens.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This has led to the creation of parallel structures and, notably, 
a ‘parallel civil service’.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description: UNDP has been an active player in accountable governance since 2002.

relations.Subject: Afghanistan
relations.Description:
Afghanistan needs significant support 
to meet human rights standards and the legal obligations as enshrined in its 
Constitution.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This, together with support to the Ministry of Justice and access to 
justice initiatives, especially for women, will constitute an integrated approach to 
justice sector reform and development.

relations.Subject: reduction
relations.Description:
Since over 80 per cent of the population depend on natural 
resources for their livelihoods — in a socio-political environment dominated by 
patronage networks — poverty reduction in Afghanistan requires direct intervention 
to ensure equitable access to assets such as land and water.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP already provides support to all provinces, and about 80 per cent of all 
districts, to improve planning, budgeting and implementation of a produc tive 
infrastructure more conducive to local development.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will also enhance the provision of energy, support environmental governance 
and build resilience to climate change and disasters.

relations.Subject: Index
relations.Description:
In 2012, the Gender Inequality Index listed Afghanistan 147th out of 
148 countries.

relations.Subject: number
relations.Description:
Finally, although the number of registered cases of violence 
against women has decreased slightly, from 6,796 cases in 2008 to 6,000 in 2012, 
the actual number of incidents of violence against women, as the Government 
acknowledged in the Millennium Development Goals Report, 2012, is much higher, as a large number of incidents go unreported.

relations.Subject: community
relations.Description:
The 
international community plays an important role in helping the country navigate this 
period from transition to transformation and achieve the goal of self-reliance.

relations.Subject: focus
relations.Description:
As the focus of assistance from the international community evolves 
from supporting security and stabilization to sustainable development and resilience, 
UNDP is planning its interventions based on assumptions derived from discussions 
of possible future scenarios.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
As the focus of assistance from the international community evolves 
from supporting security and stabilization to sustainable development and resilience, 
UNDP is planning its interventions based on assumptions derived from discussions 
of possible future scenarios.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will increase its added value by rebalancing its 
programme and maintaining a flexible stance.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
To address 
disparities across the country, UNDP will strengthen livelihoods and community 
resilience at the subnational level, and will assist Afghanistan in tackling poverty 
and sustaining economic gains.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will address the marginalization of women 
and vulnerable groups by strengthening its work with state and non-state actors, 
civil society and local communities.

relations.Subject: impact
relations.Description:
The impact of UNDP work will bring greater 
political, social, and economic opportunities for all Afghans, better systems for 
accountable governance through the rule of law, and social inclusion.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
For each country programme 
outcome, UNDP will prepare an outcome strategy document, in consultation with all 
partners and the new Government and in the light of the evolving UNAMA mandate 
after 2015.11.

Participatory planning 
will foster community ownership, leading to sustainable interventions through 
conflict-sensitive programming, the rights-based approach and ‘do no harm’ 
principles.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Using an 
issues-based approach, UNDP will ensure that synergies between outcomes and 
fields of work are established to ensure accelerated progress towards specified 
goals, fostering development impact and social cohesion.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This will involve a greater use of state and 
non-state actors in Afghanistan, and at the regional and global levels through SouthSouth cooperation, to ensure that the best national and international comparative 
experience can be integrated into the country programme outcome areas of work.

relations.Subject: support
relations.Description:
In 
coordination with UNAMA, UNDP electoral cycle support will assist national 
institutions in the better management of presidential, parliamentary and local 
election processes.

UNDP 
will support the National Assembly in building capacities to deliver on its 
constitutional mandate.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This will further the institutionalization of 
democratic processes as well as ensure equitable economic development and 
promotion of justice, the rule of law and women’s rights as core priorities of UNDP 
development interventions at the subnational level.

Building on the Afghanistan 
Peace and Reintegration Programme and possible successor arrangements, UNDP 
will adopt a two-pronged approach to address the root causes of conflict: (i)

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
At the 
national level, UNDP will work closely with UNAMA and the Ministry of Finance 
to support policy formulation, including through the use of such tools as the 
implementation of the New Deal agenda and the incorporation of peacebuilding and state building indicators into government planning processes; and (ii) At the 
provincial and district levels, UNDP will promote community-centred solutions to 
conflict through mediation efforts by provincial councils, district coordination 
councils, as well as involving traditional Shuras and Jirgas, and will facilitate 
equitable local access and management of natural resources.

relations.Subject: office
relations.Description:
As was highlighted in a risk analysis report prepared for UNDP 
in 2013, the country office will develop typologies for cross-cutting and politically 
sensitive risks when addressing peacebuilding interventions.

relations.Subject: approaches
relations.Description:
Risk management 
approaches would guide the scalability of these interventions.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This will include anti-corruption 
initiatives.

relations.Subject: partners
relations.Description:
Key partners will include the Civil Service Commission, the World Bank 
and the United Nations country team, to ensure harmonization of efforts.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This will include at least 50 per cent support 
provided through the national budget, a minimum of 80 per cent alignment to the 
national priority programmes, and collaboration with the ‘capacity-building for 
results’ initiative of the World Bank, which aims to enhance the service delivery 
capacities of key line agencies.

relations.Subject: plan
relations.Description:
The public 
financial management action plan will set out the government agenda to strengthen 
effective delivery of the national budget and increase transparency and 
accountability so as to advance anti-corruption initiatives, making use of SouthSouth and triangular cooperation.

relations.Subject: areas
relations.Description:
With the objective of increasing trust in, and access to, the fair, effective, and 
accountable rule of law, two intervention areas are envisaged: 
(a) Justice and police governance.

relations.Subject: Linkages
relations.Description:
Linkages between the Ministry of Interior, the Ministry of Justice, the Attorney 
General’s Office, and the Ministry of Women’s Affairs, and between formal and 
informal justice service providers, will ensure policy harmonization, as 
recommended by the Assessment of Development Results which recognizes 
UNDP’s clear comparative advantage.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
In coordination with the national working group on rule of law indicators, 
UNDP will support the formulation and monitoring of indicators on the 
effectiveness of justice services as well as the human rights due diligence policy on 
United Nations support to non-United Nations security forces.

relations.Subject: Literacy
relations.Description:
Literacy, 
criminal investigations, violence against women, collaboration with prosecutors, 
juvenile justice, and community-oriented policing will be important components of 
this approach.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Starting with 10 districts 
across six target provinces in 2015, UNDP will scale up its interventions to
100 districts across 20 provinces in five years, in line with its regionalization 
strategy and according to access and security conditions and application of risk 
management approaches.

relations.Subject: Outcome
relations.Description:
Outcome 3 of the country programme document promotes development that is 
equitable and inclusive.

relations.Subject: outcome
relations.Description:
The outcome will include new 
approaches to conflict prevention and resilience by increasing equitable access to 
natural resources and addressing climate change adaptation and disaster risk 
management.

relations.Subject: approach
relations.Description:
A three-pronged approach will be followed:
(a) Sustainable livelihood opportunities.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will undertake initiatives to 
facilitate local economic development in an inclusive manner by helping to create 
better economic opportunities for vulnerable populations, especially women and 
unemployed youth, through area-based approaches linked to provincial and district 
development plans, which UNDP has been engaged in since 2002 through the 
Ministry of Rural Rehabilitation and Development.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
At the national level, UNDP will support 
key economic policies called for in the national priority programmes related to 
regional integration and economic cooperation.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
At the provincial and district levels, 
UNDP will promote livelihood opportunities in the rural economy by strengthening 
the marketable skills of unemployed youth, promoting the development of entrepreneurship, supporting small-scale infrastructure, and fostering access to 
markets and sharia-compliant finance.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This could include targeted support to 
durable solutions for displaced populations, and it is expected to discourage poppy 
cultivation.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
As part of larger efforts of regional integration, UNDP may undertake 
studies and provide policy advisory services to strengthen the efforts of those 
involved in the Istanbul Process, the Istanbul Programme of Action for Least 
Developed Countries, and possibly the Central Asia Regional Economic 
Cooperation Programme.

relations.Subject: cooperation
relations.Description:
South-South and triangular cooperation with Tajikistan 
and other central Asian countries is already taking place in areas such as 
employment and local trade.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will deepen its engagement in issues that directly 
address access to natural resources and their equitable management.

relations.Subject: governance
relations.Description:
Environmental 
governance at governmental and community levels, as an integral component of 
sustainable development, will be strengthened thorough policies, plans and legal 
instruments as new opportunities with the Global Environment Facility are 
identified.

relations.Subject: promotion
relations.Description:
The promotion of off-grid, community-managed and owned, clean and 
renewable energy services will be a specific focus area.

relations.Subject: projects
relations.Description:
Initial pilot projects will 
target seven provinces for three years.

relations.Subject: work
relations.Description:
Policy-level work in this sector 
will include the development of legal and regulatory instruments for rural energy at 
the village level, as well as improving the interface between the national and 
village-level energy structures.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
In the extractive industries sector, UNDP will work 
on an initiative with the World Bank, the National Environmental Protection 
Agency, the Ministry of Agriculture, Irrigation and Livestock, and the Ministry of 
Mines, to reduce the negative effects of mining on ecosystems and to ensure 
community involvement.

relations.Subject: Support
relations.Description:
Support will be scaled up to 10 provinces by the end of the 
programme period.

relations.Subject: work
relations.Description:
Policy formulation work will include assistance on finalizing a 
climate change strategy and action plan with the National Environmental Protection 
Agency, while regional cooperation for disaster risk management will be pursued 
through the Istanbul Process.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
In 
cooperation with the Ministry of Women’s Affairs, UNAMA and UN-Women, 
UNDP will focus on three interventions:
(a) Government capacity to meet women’s rights.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support the 
Government in implementing legal commitments, both national and international, 
that affect the lives of women.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
To increase the 
responsiveness of government ministries to citizens’ rights, UNDP supports 
advocacy, through civil society organizations and women’s groups, for the inclusion 
of emerging citizen priorities in national and subnational planning frameworks.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
In 
addition to the capacity to implement technical and financial support, in partnership 
with civil society organizations, through advocacy measures, UNDP will strengthen 
the capacity of the Ministry of Women’s Affairs and civil society organizations to 
monitor and report on the implementation of the international and national 
commitments of the Government.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will make use of new technology and 
knowledge-sharing platforms, such as cooperation exchange mechanisms, to achieve 
that aim.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Recognizing the challenge of access at the subnational level due to insecurity 
and limited infrastructure, and the need to ensure closer monitoring of projects and 
interactions with beneficiaries, UNDP is implementing a regionalization strategy 
that will transform UNDP project-based hubs into UNDP regional sub-offices.

relations.Subject: that
relations.Description:
This 
will be complemented by partnership and communication strategies and a risk 
management strategy — which are being developed — that will propose an outreach 
model at the regional and provincial levels, in addition to approaches for scaling up 
interventions.

relations.Subject: hubs
relations.Description:
The UNDP regional hubs will be co-located with other United Nations 
organizations, where possible, to guide area-based programming and synergies 
among outcomes.

relations.Subject: proximity
relations.Description:
Greater proximity to communities will enable UNDP to better assess needs, improve targeting of interventions, collect 
better-quality data, and facilitate the monitoring of activities.

relations.Subject: Regionalization
relations.Description:
Regionalization will 
improve programme synergies and increase operational efficiency thanks to 
clustering and common premises and services.

relations.Subject: strategy
relations.Description:
While this regionalization strategy presents 
certain risks related to security, access, oversight capacity and financial 
sustainability, the sub-offices, by improving interactions with local partners, 
collecting better local knowledge and data, and conducting provincial conflict 
analysis, will allow programmes to be scaled up and expanded through scenario 
planning when security conditions and infrastructure become more favourable.

relations.Subject: Mechanisms
relations.Description:
Mechanisms such as joint provincial visits and sharing of data from sub-offices 
would be additional means of cooperation.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
As the assessment of development results notes, UNDP must increase its ties 
with civil society, both as a means of delivering its programmes and to enhance 
accountability, counter corruption, and promote gender equality.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This could include people with disabilities and those living 
with HIV.

relations.Subject: document
relations.Description:
This country programme document outlines UNDP contributions to national 
results and serves as the primary unit of accountability to the Executive Board for results alignment and resources assigned to the programme at the country level.

relations.Subject: execution
relations.Description:
National 
execution will be the preferred modality, to be replaced by direct execution for all or 
part of the programme if required to enable response to major capacit y weaknesses 
and/or force majeure.

relations.Subject: office
relations.Description:
The country office will rearrange its internal programme structure to deliver 
the four outcomes, and each outcome will be housed in one programme team.

This 
will increase programme coherence and allow for an issues-based approach to 
providing development solutions.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support joint 
capacity assessments and a common approach to risk management, ensuring full 
compliance with the principles of the harmonized approach to cash transfers.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
To facilitate a targeted risk mitigation strategy, UNDP has created three 
categories: strategic, external and internal risks.

relations.Subject: risks
relations.Description:
Strategic risks include political 
pressure, implementation modality constraints, and limitations related to on-budget 
delivery mechanisms.

relations.Subject: risks
relations.Description:
External risks include reduced access at the subnational and 
community levels due to deterioration in security conditions, shrinking donor funds, 
weak infrastructure, limited capacity of implementing partners, and corruption.

relations.Subject: risks
relations.Description:
Internal risks include staff turnover and capacity, and inadequacy of oversight and 
accountability measures and financial management systems.

relations.Subject: impact
relations.Description:
The impact of these 
could include reputational loss, mismanagement of funds, inefficiency in 
programme interventions, and inability to implement, monitor and evaluate 
activities effectively.

relations.Subject: transition
relations.Description:
The transition in the Law and Order Trust Fund for 
Afghanistan, in particular, will require a targeted risk management approach.

relations.Subject: These
relations.Description:
These will include the 
proactive use of programme criticality assessments and innovative approaches for 
data collection and analysis of results.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP has also established a dedicated audit and investigations capacity, 
and programme criticality levels have been established for UNDP activities, all of 
which are undertaken in compliance with this United Nations-wide framework.

relations.Subject: Operating
relations.Description:
Operating in a fragile context with high levels of insecurity, minimal local 
information management systems, and a lack of comprehensive, accurate data has 
been a key challenge for monitoring and evaluation efforts.

relations.Subject: challenges
relations.Description:
These 
challenges have cost implications at the programme and project levels which will 
have to be addressed.

relations.Subject: programme
relations.Description:
The new country programme will intensify efforts in monitoring and utilizing 
data collection to continuously assess impact.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will also use 
the newly established Civil Society Advisory Committee as a mechanism through 
which to partner with selected civil society organizations to monitor programmes in 
their respective areas of expertise.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This will 
facilitate the validation of results, the generation of lessons learned and the 
continuous assessment of UNDP contributions to outcomes.

relations.Subject: monitoring
relations.Description:
Specific monitoring and 
evaluation methods will include third-party monitoring, regular UNDP verification 
missions, and quantitative surveys.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP and the United Nations system as a whole 
will explore satellite surveillance, mobile phone monitoring, and the use of other 
innovative methodologies for monitoring in fragile and insecure environments.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support joint United Nations efforts to develop national 
institutional capacity to collect, update, analyse and utilize statistical and 
monitoring data to strengthen evidenced-based development policies and strategies 
through national systems.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support certain counterpart 
ministries in collecting data related to their sectors.

relations.Subject: chart
relations.Description:
The bar chart shows the proportion of a country's land 
area in each of these classes and the global distribution of land area 
across the classes (for comparison).

relations.Subject: chart
relations.Description:
The bar chart 
shows the distribution of the country's land area in each of these classes 
compared to the global distribution of wind resources.

relations.Subject: chart
relations.Description: The chart shows the average NPP in the country

relations.Subject: trade
relations.Description:
Energy trade includes all 
commodities in Chapter 27 of the Harmonised System (HS).

Language: EN
------------------------------------------------

UNECE Renewable Energy Uptake

relations.Subject: Albania
relations.Description:
With 45% of the total primary energy supply (TPES), Albania has one of the largest shares of renewable energy in 
its energy mix in South-East Europe.

relations.Subject: Albania
relations.Description:
In addition to hydropower resources, Albania also has 
abundant solar and wind resources, which are currently almost entirely untapped.

relations.Subject: Albania
relations.Description:
Within Europe, Albania has some of the highest sunshine hours per year, representing significant potential for 
solar energy development.

relations.Subject: south
relations.Description:
The coastal south and far north of the country also hold immense potential for wind 
power development.

relations.Subject: solar
relations.Description: Both solar and wind could effectively complement the existent hydropower fleet.

relations.Subject: Plan
relations.Description:
The current National Renewable Energy Action Plan (NREAP) sets a target of 38% for the renewable energy 
share of total final energy consumption (TFEC) by 2020.

relations.Subject: NREAP
relations.Description:
The NREAP also stipulates technology-specific deployment targets to achieve this goal: 7MW hydropower, 
490MW solar PV, 50MW wind and 41MW waste-to-power by 2020, which have not yet been reached.

relations.Subject: Strategy
relations.Description:
The National Energy Sector Strategy (2018) formulates a target of 42% of renewable energy in the TPES by 2030 
which has already been achieved.;

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This requires more 
sophisticated network infrastructure and operation that can handle bidirectional energy flows and changing 
supply profiles.

Particularly in high-demand centres such as the capital Tirana, the Albanian distribution grid 
lacks sufficient capacity and dynamic operation to handle variable electricity injection.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This severely hampers 
the successful integration of renewable energy sources in the country.
#Improving support mechanisms for renewable energy

relations.Subject: revision
relations.Description:
Considering this, a revision of the 
existing support landscape for RE in Albania would foster the deployment of small-scale projects in the country.

relations.Subject: risking
relations.Description: Further de-risking of renewable energy projects would entice private investment and accelerate development.

relations.Subject: instruments
relations.Description:
Thoroughly developed planning 
and financial instruments such as Power Purchase Agreements, for example, would inspire confidence and
stimulate international investment in renewable energy in Albania.

relations.Subject: Association
relations.Description:
Albania Energy Association represents the interests of Albanian and international energy producers;


relations.Subject: Association
relations.Description:
Albanian Renewable Energy Association (AREA) represents the interests of renewable energy producers in Albania;
#

relations.Subject: EBRD
relations.Description: EBRD, Albania’s solar tender generates competitive price, 2020

relations.Subject: dena
relations.Description:
Through various projects, dena supports the German government in 
implementing energy and climate policy goals.

relations.Subject: elections
relations.Description:
The 2017 general elections ushered in a new era in Angola, with a change of President after 38 
years.

relations.Subject: Advances
relations.Description:
Advances in democracy and rights are taking place in a context of tight fiscal space and 
deceleration of economic growth,
as result of the sharp decrease in oil prices and its related tax 
revenues.

relations.Subject: Angola
relations.Description:
The 2018 Multiple Overlapping 
Deprivation Analysis (MODA) on multidimensional child poverty in Angola concluded that 
77.4 per cent of children under 18 are poor.6 The Gini coefficient was 0.43 in 2008.Due to higher 
life expectancy, Angola improved its human development index (HDI) to medium human 
development status, ranking 147 out of 189 countries in 2017, with an HDI of 0.581.8 The tight 
fiscal space underscoresthe importance of increased private investments that support achievement
of the Sustainable Development Goals.

relations.Subject: Ease
relations.Description:
The 2019 World Bank Ease of Doing Business Report ranks Angola 
173 out of 190 countries.

relations.Subject: country

relations.Subject: ages

Young people 
ages 15 to 24 face higher unemployment rates, at 52.4 per cent.

relations.Subject: Angola
relations.Description:
Angola presents high maternal, child and youth mortality rates, and a high incidence of malaria, 
tuberculosis and other communicable and non-communicable diseases.

relations.Subject: determinants
relations.Description:
Social determinants of health in Angola include the limited knowledge of 
prevention methods and access to prevention commodities, high cost of treatment and related 
services, poor housing and sanitation, and gender inequalities.

relations.Subject: change
relations.Description: Climate change has severely affected Angola.

relations.Subject: drought
relations.Description:
In 2012-2016, El Niño-induced drought in the
southern provinces caused $750 million in damages and losses, with 1.2 million people affected, 
mostly women and children.

relations.Subject: people
relations.Description:
In 2012-2016, El Niño-induced drought in the
southern provinces caused $750 million in damages and losses, with 1.2 million people affected, 
mostly women and children.

relations.Subject: Government
relations.Description:
The Government has developed a drought recovery framework for 
2018-2022, including the investment plan to enhance resilience.

relations.Subject: Angola
relations.Description:
Angola has large protected areas and is planning its first marine 
protected area.

relations.Subject: management
relations.Description:
Solid waste management remains a challenge, with 1.3 million tonnes of 
household waste produced yearly in the capital.

relations.Subject: Angola
relations.Description:
Angola has made a strong commitment through 
its nationally determined contributions to reduce carbon emissions by 35 per cent.

relations.Subject: Government
relations.Description:
Although the Government promotes private investment in renewables, and there is 
growing private interest, the insufficient legal and regulatory environment, low cost of 
conventional energy, and limited access to foreign currency remain barriers.

relations.Subject: rights
relations.Description:
Gender and women’s rights and participation remain a challenge because of patriarchal 
customs and practices.

relations.Subject: Women
relations.Description:
Women represent 35.5 per cent of senior government positions.17 Gender 
barriers remain inherent in the HIV context, such as unequal age of consent to marry and gaps in 
sexual and reproductive health rights.

relations.Subject: Plan
relations.Description:
The National Development Plan (NDP), 2018-2022, has six pillars: (a) human development 
and wellbeing; (b) inclusive, diversified and sustainable economic development; (c) infrastructure 
for development; (d) democracy, good governance, state reform and decentralization; 
(e) harmonious development of territory; and (f) stability, territorial integrity and the country’s 
role in the regional and international contexts.

relations.Subject: Angola
relations.Description:
As Angola is undergoing political reforms and addressing major economic challenges, the 
NDP, 2018-2022, puts significant emphasis on maintaining stability and peace.

relations.Subject: office
relations.Description:
Over the last three years, the UNDP country office has undergone a major transformation and 
is, at the start of the next country programme, a convener of multiple partners for the Goals and 
Agenda 2030.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP delivers quality policy advice and technical support and assists Angola in 
meeting targets and requirements of complex funding mechanisms, such as the Global 
Environment Facility and the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria.

relations.Subject: programme
relations.Description:
The programme includes integrated solutions 
to complex, interconnected development challenges.

relations.Subject: priorities
relations.Description:
Three complementary priorities define the 
2020-2022 programme:
(a) fostering poverty eradication and inclusive economic growth;
(b) increasing resilience to shocks and crises and enhancing management of natural 
resources for conservation and economic development; and
(c) strengthening inclusive democracy, human rights, justice and rule of law.

relations.Subject: programme
relations.Description:
The country 
programme will support Angola in effectively managing its development resources and bolstering
the voice of those furthest behind and their ability to hold government accountable.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Within the three 
programme components, UNDP will support the Government on the overarching national 
objective in the NDP, 2018-2022, of maintaining stability and peace.

relations.Subject: programme
relations.Description:
Operationalizing General Assembly resolution 72/279 on the repositioning of the United 
Nations development system, the country programme represents the UNDP vehicle for deliveringas-one in Angola, guided by its United Nations Development Assistance Framework (UNDAF).

relations.Subject: programme
relations.Description:
The country programme directly supports the country’s international commitments, including 
Agenda 2030, African Union Agenda 2063, the NDP, 2018-2022 and key national strategies, and 
the UNDP Strategic Plan, 2018-2021.

relations.Subject: Innovation
relations.Description: Innovation will be a core element of the country programme.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will devote 5 per cent of 
its core budget to delivering innovative solutions to development challenges.

relations.Subject: office
relations.Description:
The UNDP country 
office is establishing an accelerator lab to create a learning network to test innovative ways of 
addressing development challenges.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will significantly deepen its engagement to end poverty in Angola and reduce 
inequality through substantive analysis, dialogue and technical advice to develop more effective
national policies and programmes.

relations.Subject: cooperation
relations.Description:
The accelerator lab and South-South and triangular 
cooperation will be vehicles for prototyping new solutions.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will strengthen 
its partnership with the Government on analytics of expenditures and loan portfolio, measuring 
their impact in achieving the Goals.

relations.Subject: assistance
relations.Description: UNDP assistance will have two main elements.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will continue 
its youth internship programme and enhance it with the national volunteer programme.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:

engaged private sector platform through the umbrella of the Angolan Corporate Social 
Responsibility Network and Public-Private Partnership Initiative.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will strengthen its support to national efforts for sustainable solutions in health, in line 
with the UNDP HIV, health and development strategy, 2016-2022 (HHD).

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Building on its Global 
Fund principal recipient role, UNDP will deliver packages of HIV prevention services to 
adolescent girls and young women, female sex workers, men having sex with men, and treatment 
services to people living with HIV, including pregnant women.

relations.Subject: men
relations.Description:
Building on its Global 
Fund principal recipient role, UNDP will deliver packages of HIV prevention services to 
adolescent girls and young women, female sex workers, men having sex with men, and treatment 
services to people living with HIV, including pregnant women.

relations.Subject: approach
relations.Description:
The UNDP core programming 
approach will be the social empowerment of these population groups through capacity 
development, involvement in service delivery and advocacy for sexual and reproductive health 
and rights.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
To reduce gender, legal and human rights-related barriers to accessing basic social services, 
UNDP will promote national ownership of the 2018 HIV legal environment assessment report 
and the national strategy for key populations, and revision of the 2004 HIV law.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will 
deliver capacity-building packages for advocacy to CSOs.

relations.Subject: partners
relations.Description:
Key UNDP partners include National 
HIV/AIDS Institute (INLS,)

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Building on the NDP, 2018-2022, commitments and early achievements in non-fossil fuel 
options, UNDP will support low-carbon development.

relations.Subject: investments
relations.Description:
The UNDP de-risking renewable energy 
investments (DREI) initiative will provide policy support to boost private investments in 
renewable energies, including in remote areas.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP is supporting private investment in off-grid 
solutions, and renewable electricity for public infrastructure, including in the health sector.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Through policy advice and implementation of GEF projects, UNDP will support the 
Government in the conservation of forest and protected areas by rehabilitating infrastructure, 
training, equipment, preparation of management plans, surveys of flora and fauna, engagement 
with communities, combatting illegal wildlife trade, and establishing the first marine protected 
areas.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will scale up gender responsive disaster and climate risk management support, building 
on its demonstrated results, adopting an integrated approach to resilience.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description: UNDP will provide training to strengthen capacities to cope with shocks and crises.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Addressing the country’s solid waste management challenge, UNDP will provide technical 
and financial assistance to promote recycling, through the UNDP country accelerator lab, and 
support the elimination of toxic waste.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Through integration and synergies within the country 
programme areas, UNDP will support entrepreneurship and promote green jobs, including for 
biodiversity and waste management.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will facilitate access to international funding, 
including through GEF, Green Climate Fund (GCF), and South-South and triangular cooperation.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support efforts to ensure the first-ever elected local governments deliver on 
promises for democratic development and improved local service delivery.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will strengthen 
the capacity of elected local governance institutions and support participation mechanisms, such 
as participatory budgeting and civil society involvement in policy formulation, implementation 
and monitoring.

relations.Subject: partners
relations.Description:
Key partners include MAT, MASFAMU, Parliament, local governments, CSOs 
and bilateral donor partners.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
Through technical support and South-South and triangular cooperation with countries such as 
Brazil and Cabo Verde, UNDP will support transparency and accountability in public 
management to improve services and finance development.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will coordinate international 
assistance for the implementation of the national anti-corruption strategy, 2018-2022, launched 
with UNDP support.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will support the capacity of justice and human rights institutions at national and local 
levels to handle citizens’ grievances and address human rights cases, including economic, social 
and cultural rights.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This includes the core ombudsman function of the Provedor de Justiça and its
possible accreditation as the national human rights institution (NHRI).

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will promote the inclusion of women in development and service delivery and their 
effective participation and representation in decision-making processes.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description: UNDP will support the participation of youth in governance processes by advocating for proyouth participatory processes and mechanisms.

Together with other United Nations organizations, UNDP 
will implement the joint programming framework and business operations strategy as part of 
delivering-as-one.

relations.Subject: office
relations.Description:
The country office will review its capacity to ensure it is positioned for effective programme
implementation.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will mitigate development financing risks by advocating for budget prioritization and 
reinforcement of national capacities in result-based budgeting.

relations.Subject: office
relations.Description:
The country office is developing a country programme action plan (CPAP), which 
includes a partnerships strategy and action plan for resource mobilization, with Bureau of External 
Relations and Advocacy (BERA) support, and a communication strategy.

relations.Subject: projects
relations.Description:
All projects will undergo systematic review to ensure environmental and social safeguards, 
costs and benefits of an intervention are evaluated in accordance with UNDP policies and 
standards.

relations.Subject: office
relations.Description:
The country office will invoke the 
business continuity plan in the case of crises affecting its normal operations.

relations.Subject: document
relations.Description:
This country programme document outlines UNDP contributions to national results and serves 
as the primary unit of accountability to the Board for results alignment and resources assigned to 
the programme at country level.

relations.Subject: framework
relations.Description:
A strong results framework (annex A) supports monitoring and evaluation of the country 
programme, aligned with national priorities, the UNDAF, 2020-2022, the UNDP Strategic Plan, 
2018-2021, the Goals and other international and national commitments.

relations.Subject: UNDP
relations.Description:
UNDP will use, as far as possible, the national statistical systems and Goals targets to monitor 
its contribution to national results.

relations.Subject: policy
relations.Description:
This policy will be a component of National Energy Policy of Afghanistan to be 
developed by MEW.

relations.Subject: Afghanistan
relations.Description:
While Afghanistan is a late starter in providing access to clean energy to its rural population, it 
embarks on the journey with considerable advantages.

relations.Subject: country
relations.Description:
While the country presents unique opportunities and challenges, 
there is relevant experience in similar terrains, political, environmental and social contexts to 
enable the creation of a suite of policy measures more likely to lead to successful outcomes.

relations.Subject: electrification
relations.Description:
Rural electrification can thus facilitate social service delivery and 
help improve the well-being of those living below the National Poverty Line without 
access to renewable energy supplies.

relations.Subject: Displacing
relations.Description:
Displacing 
greenhouse gas emissions will provide significant global climate change benefits.

relations.Subject: facilitate
relations.Description:
To facilitate private sector participation as rural energy service providers, rural service 
delivery mechanisms may involve energy service companies, equipment dealers or 
cooperatives.

relations.Subject: credit
relations.Description:
Long-term consumer credit through a microfinance 
organization may be one mechanism to address initial costs.

relations.Subject: installations
environment
relations.Description:
An enabling environment requires the introduction of certain regulatory measures from the 
Government to attract private sector and promote sustainability.

relations.Subject: measures
relations.Description:
These regulatory measures 
will include: 
• Developing an appropriate legal framework for pricing and tariff structures, working 
with rural communities to support the integration of renewable energy into the 
economy and attract private sector investment.

relations.Subject: barriers
relations.Description:
The significant barriers to the implementation of renewable energy that need to be addressed 
include: 
• Poor institutional framework and infrastructure at the sub-national level for rural 
energy promotion ;
• Quality of equipment and services related to the renewable energy system installations. ;
• Poor baseline data availability; and lack of information on local renewable energy 
resources.

relations.Subject: energy
relations.Description:
For the purpose of this Policy, renewable energy includes the following: 
1. hydropower plants 
2.

relations.Subject: Some
relations.Description:
Some of the wind and solar projects may require hybrid solutions to provide continuous 
energy supply.

relations.Subject: Subsidies
relations.Description:
;
#5.1.1 Mini/Micro-Hydropower Plants 
Subsidies will be provided for the implementation of mini/micro-hydro plants up to 1 MW 
capacity through an appropriate delivery mechanism.

relations.Subject: projects
relations.Description:
These projects 
will essentially comprise remote sites or represent areas characterized by uneconomic levels of 
power demand.

relations.Subject: Government
relations.Description:
The 
Government will develop regulatory frameworks for independent power producers, including 
power purchase agreements and a standardized framework for tariffs.

relations.Subject: Strengthening
relations.Description:
Strengthening private entrepreneurship will be an important strategy to fulfil rural energy 
needs.

relations.Subject: Government
relations.Description:
The 
Government will facilitate the provision of credit, certificate or licensing procedures for private 
sector, power tariffs, and capital cost subsidies for projects that support the development of 
rural energy systems.

relations.Subject: approaches
relations.Description:
Effective policy approaches for reaching the poorest may combine private sector involvement 
with targeted public subsidies linked to development objectives and strategies for increasing 
incomes.

relations.Subject: which
relations.Description:
In consideration of the high capital costs for many rural electrification options and the low cash 
capacity of rural households, innovative small-scale, affordable financing mechanisms will need 
to be developed, which may include micro-credit, leasing, prepaid meters and fees for service 
provision.

relations.Subject: Government
relations.Description:
The Government will investigate the potential for micro-credit financing of 
renewable energy projects.

relations.Subject: Government
relations.Description:
The Government may provide subsidies to communities to target the poorest segments 
of the population in rural areas.

relations.Subject: introduction
relations.Description:
The introduction of energy efficiency, coupled with renewable energy technology in rural areas, 
will help rural consumers by reducing supply constraint and lowering their own energy 
expenditure.

relations.Subject: measures
relations.Description:
Energy efficiency measures in off-grid and grid-connected systems will reduce 
costs through lower generation investment costs and reduced energy usage, and will also abate 
pollution and displace the importation of fossil fuels.

relations.Subject: stakeholders
relations.Description: The institutional stakeholders in renewable energy in Afghanistan include the following.

ICE 
brought together a range of Government and donor interests to assure coordinated action and 
practical planning.

relations.Subject: committee
relations.Description:
The ICE Sub-committee on 
Renewable Energy and Rural Electrification brought together Government agencies, donors and 
non-governmental actors involved in the sector.

relations.Subject: MEW
relations.Description:
MEW has overall responsibility for electrification, mainly to provide energy needs to the bulk of 
the population.

relations.Subject: MEW
relations.Description:
MEW launched National 
Energy Supply Program (NESP) as a National Proirity Program (NPP) under infrastructure 
development cluster to develop larger sized generation and expansion of transmission and 
distribution networks.

relations.Subject: Program
relations.Description:
MEW launched National 
Energy Supply Program (NESP) as a National Proirity Program (NPP) under infrastructure 
development cluster to develop larger sized generation and expansion of transmission and 
distribution networks.

relations.Subject: MRRD
relations.Description: MRRD has general oversight of delivery of all non-farm programmes in rural Afghanistan.

relations.Subject: MRRD
relations.Description:
Through its 
provincial offices, MRRD has a point of liaison with provincial governments.

relations.Subject: NSP
relations.Description:
MRRD has been the principal arm of the Government in promoting rural 
electrification through its programs: NSP has supported energy access to rural areas through 
the installation of micro-hydropower plants, solar home systems and diesel generators.

MRRD 
launched Energy for Rural Development in Afghanistan (ERDA) under the National Area-Based 
Development Programme (NABDP) in 2008 to address sustainability issues related to rural 
energy projects.

relations.Subject: cases
relations.Description: many cases include renewable rural energy projects that meet the local demand.

relations.Subject: MRRD
relations.Description:
In case, MRRD is implementing projects above 100 kW capacity, it 
will be coordinated with MEW and the MEW when implementing projects below 100 kW in the 
rural area will be coordinated with MRRD.

relations.Subject: REED
relations.Description:
REED will clarify current relevant practices in renewable energy development for rural area, set 
out standards and codes of practice for adoption, and establish implementation procedures and 
guidelines to attract and facilitate donor assistance and private investment in renewable energy 
and rural electrification.

relations.Subject: REED
relations.Description:
REED will liaise with the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Economy, MEW, the National 
Environment Protection Agency (NEPA), the Afghanistan National Standards Authority (ANSA) 
and other relevant Government institutions on standardization, maximizing the socio-economic 
impact of rural electrification while minimizing environmental hazards.

relations.Subject: REED
relations.Description:
At technical level, REED and RED will convene a Technical Working Group to include 
representatives from MEW, NEPA, ANSA, MRRD, the Ministry of Mines, the Ministry of Public 
Health, the Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Agriculture, Irrigation and Livestock, donors, 
sector NGOs and any other pertinent body, to coordinate renewable energy development and 
delivery of renewable energy services to key economic and social sectors.

relations.Subject: REED
relations.Description:
REED will maintain close liaison with NEPA in working towards accession to the Kyoto Protocol, 
and to develop and coordinate Clean Development Mechanism projects designed to qualify for 
carbon credits to reduce the cost of investment in renewable energy rural electrification.

relations.Subject: REED
relations.Description:
REED and RED will develop a database for the assessment and implementation of rural 
renewable energy projects, and disseminate this information to all decision-making bodies on 
all levels.

relations.Subject: participants
relations.Description:
In the interest of coordination, all participants will coordinate activities in renewable energy 
and rural electrification with REED of MRRD and RED of MEW.

relations.Subject: development
relations.Description:
The purpose of the RREP is to create the conditions for the development of renewable 
technology for rural communities to meet their energy demand.

relations.Subject: Government
relations.Description:
The Government will adopt a 
phased, managed and partnership approach to renewable energy projects that are well 
conceived and show the potential to providing acceptable social, environmental and financial 
returns for all investors and stakeholders.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This will lessen the strain on fiscal resources and 
hold greater potential for successful implementation.

relations.Subject: environment
relations.Description:
An appropriate enabling environment towards full commercial operation will nurture the 
technologies that are proven to meet these Policy objectives.

relations.Subject: Report
relations.Description:
This Report presents the modelling framework, data, analyses and conclusions of the year-long activity 
undertaken by the Scientific Research Institute for Energy (SRIE), under sub-contract to Tetra Tech ES Inc. as 
the lead implementing partner for the USAID Market Liberalization and Energy Trade (MLET) Program, to 
prepare an update of the Armenia Least Cost Energy Development Plan (LCEDP) for the years 2020-
2036.

relations.Subject: lead
relations.Description:
This Report presents the modelling framework, data, analyses and conclusions of the year-long activity 
undertaken by the Scientific Research Institute for Energy (SRIE), under sub-contract to Tetra Tech ES Inc. as 
the lead implementing partner for the USAID Market Liberalization and Energy Trade (MLET) Program, to 
prepare an update of the Armenia Least Cost Energy Development Plan (LCEDP) for the years 2020-
2036.

relations.Subject: work
relations.Description:
This work utilized the Integrated MARKAL-EFOM System (TIMES) model which is an economic model 
generator for local, national, multi-regional, or global energy systems, developed and maintained under the 
auspices of the International Energy Agency’s Energy Technology Systems Analysis Program, which provides a 
technology-rich basis for representing energy dynamics over a multi-period time horizon.

relations.Subject: platform
relations.Description:
The TIMES model platform provides an integrated energy system modelling tool designed to guide policy 
formulation over a wide range of energy, economic and environmental planning and policy issues, helping to 
establish investment priorities within a comprehensive framework.

relations.Subject: employs
relations.Description:
Key features of the TIMES platform include 
that it encompasses the entire energy system from resource extraction through to end-use demands; employs 
least-cost optimization to identify the most cost-effective pattern of resource use and technology deployment 
over time; provides a framework to evaluate medium- to long-term policies and programs that can impact the 
evolution of the energy system; and quantifies the costs and technology choices that result from imposing those 
policies and program.

relations.Subject: team
relations.Description:
In order to adapt the generic TIMES model to become the TIMES-Armenia model, the SRIE team first 
established as a base year that period for which there was a complete set of data on production and 
consumption of all energy carriers used in Armenia - the energy balance.

relations.Subject: results
relations.Description:
When this set of added constraints was applied to the 
baseline model, the results established the Baseline Reference (BASE-R) Scenario.

relations.Subject: fact
relations.Description:
The fact that the full constrained amount of solar and wind capacity is selected by the 
model as part of the least cost solution for new generation under all scenarios 
underscores the importance to Armenia of ensuring a policy and institutional 
environment that supports full realization of new VRES generation to the maximum 
extent practicable, not only to ensure the lowest cost generation but also to minimize 
reliance on other imported energy sources and to strengthen Armenia’s energy 
security and competitiveness.

relations.Subject: rates
relations.Description:
While these higher (lower) growth rates had the expected impact in regard to increasing (decreasing) total 
system costs, total primary energy supply, final energy consumption and electricity generation, it was especially 
interesting to note that the higher GDP growth rate also reduced the share of total system cost in GDP, owing 
to the fact that it was accompanied by significant lowering of the energy intensity of a unit of GDP.

relations.Subject: This
relations.Description:
This reflects the fact that aggregate purchases of new energy demand devices increase by 
almost 19%, which embeds higher levels of efficiency over time as incomes rise.

relations.Subject: there
relations.Description:
While there are slight variations in the implementation 
schedule for new solar, wind and hydro power capacity, the only effect of higher 
(lower) income growth lies in the increased (decreased) utilization of existing installed 
capacity of both VRES and gas-fired thermal power plants, with a concomitant 
increase (decrease) in expenditures on natural gas fuel.

relations.Subject: effect
relations.Description:
While there are slight variations in the implementation 
schedule for new solar, wind and hydro power capacity, the only effect of higher 
(lower) income growth lies in the increased (decreased) utilization of existing installed 
capacity of both VRES and gas-fired thermal power plants, with a concomitant 
increase (decrease) in expenditures on natural gas fuel.

relations.Subject: considering
relations.Description:
Thus, whether considering total system cost or investment costs required for new generation, 
the scenarios for life extension of the ANPP represent a least-cost policy choice for continuing to maintain 
nuclear capacity in Armenia’ energy mix.

relations.Subject: Commitment
relations.Description:
Commitment, either by 2036 or earlier, largely mirror the “new nuclear” scenarios in 
terms of increases in total system cost and primary energy supply, reductions in GHG 
emissions and decreases in imports of natural gas for electricity generation.

relations.Subject: We
relations.Description:
We also explored two 
scenarios with lower gas prices, starting from the same initial border gas price effective from January 1, 2019, 
of US$ 165 per 1000 m3 , which i) applied the EU trend growth rate over the entire period to 2036 from that 
starting point , and ii) assumed that the border gas prices grows to US$ 180/1000 m3 by 2027 and remains 
fixed at that level until the end of the planning period.

relations.Subject: which
relations.Description:
We also explored two 
scenarios with lower gas prices, starting from the same initial border gas price effective from January 1, 2019, 
of US$ 165 per 1000 m3 , which i) applied the EU trend growth rate over the entire period to 2036 from that 
starting point , and ii) assumed that the border gas prices grows to US$ 180/1000 m3 by 2027 and remains 
fixed at that level until the end of the planning period.

relations.Subject: which
relations.Description:
It is useful to note that the constrained levels of solar and 
wind generation are still fully built, which generates an investment cost saving as compared to BASE-R of $377 
million in the case with the EU trend to 2036 and of $391 million when the gas price is capped at $180.

relations.Subject: we
relations.Description:
To 
explore these opportunities, we examined scenarios designed to increase the penetration level for use of 
electricity in residential heating to 25% in 2027 and to 50% by 2036, increase the penetration level for use of 
electric vehicles to 25% in 2027 and to 50% by 2036 and both of these scenarios taken together.

relations.Subject: Report
relations.Description:
This Report presents the modelling framework, data, analyses and conclusions of the year-long activity 
undertaken by the Scientific Research Institute for Energy (SRIE), under sub-contract to Tetra Tech ES Inc. as 
the lead implementing partner for the USAID Market Liberalization and Energy Trade (MLET) Program, to 
prepare an update of the Armenia Least Cost Energy Development Plan (LCEDP) for the years 2020-2036.

relations.Subject: lead
relations.Description:
This Report presents the modelling framework, data, analyses and conclusions of the year-long activity 
undertaken by the Scientific Research Institute for Energy (SRIE), under sub-contract to Tetra Tech ES Inc. as 
the lead implementing partner for the USAID Market Liberalization and Energy Trade (MLET) Program, to 
prepare an update of the Armenia Least Cost Energy Development Plan (LCEDP) for the years 2020-2036.

relations.Subject: sections
relations.Description:
The remaining sections of this Chapter summarize a description of the 
Armenian energy system in the modelling base year of 2016.

relations.Subject: Chapter
relations.Description:
Chapter 2 presents a brief summary of the platform and methodology for the generic TIMES model, which is an 
economic model generator for local, national, multi-regional, or global energy systems, developed and 
maintained under the auspices of the International Energy Agency’s Energy Technology Systems Analysis 
Program (IEA - ETSAP).

relations.Subject: model
relations.Description:
This model provides a technology-rich basis for representing energy dynamics over a 
multi-period time horizon.

relations.Subject: Chapter
relations.Description:
Chapter 3 provides details on the specific application of the TIMES-Armenia model, 
confirming the calibration of the model to the year first modelled year (2018), confirming results to match 
available data, and presents the process of developing the initial Baseline (or Reference) scenario for the period 
planning period 2020 – 2036.

relations.Subject: Chapter
relations.Description:
With the Baseline-Reference scenario fully detailed, Chapter 4 outlines a set of selected alternative possible 
scenarios that were identified by key stakeholders as of interest, to reflect different potential pathways for the 
evolution of the Armenian energy system, including policy choices as well as sensitivity analyses to determine 
the possible impacts of variations in such factors as demand growth or energy processes.

relations.Subject: Chapter
relations.Description:
Once the results of the various scenarios have been 
described and the differences in outcomes explored, Chapter 5 presents a set of summary conclusions and 
recommendations based on those results.

relations.Subject: there
relations.Description:
Following the Spitak earthquake on December 7, 1988, operation of the ANPP stopped for safety 
considerations, although there was no technical damage to the plant.

relations.Subject: Rivers
relations.Description:
The Hrazdan River, flowing out of Lake Sevan, and the Araks, Vorotan, and Debet 
Rivers have the most energy potential.

relations.Subject: cascade
cascade
relations.Description:
The cascade comprises Spandaryan 
HPP (76 MW), Shamb HPP (171 MW) and Tatev HPP (157 MW) with a total installed capacity of 404 
MW and a designed annual electricity generation of 1.16 billion kWh.

relations.Subject: Construction
system
relations.Description:
In terms of other renewable energy resources, in 2016 Armenia’s system also had one wind farm with a 
capacity of 2.64 MW and at the end of the year there were a small number of solar PV plants installed, with 
capacity of 273 kW and annual generation less than 0.1 million kWh

relations.Subject: GENERATION
relations.Description:
#ELECTRICITY GENERATION AND CONSUMPTION IN 2016, in MILLION kWh:

relations.Subject: consumption
relations.Description: Export is 1,226.4 and Import 272.6 while Final consumption is 5,328.2 with a Number of Consumers of ~ 985,000.

relations.Subject: numbers
relations.Description:
These numbers present the shares of electricity generation in 2016 by fuel, which shows that the ANPP, gas-fired 
power plants and renewables (including small HPPs and wind) were distributed almost equally in the total 
generation mix, each accounting for around one-third of the total.

relations.Subject: Figure
relations.Description:
Figure 1.2 presents the amount of electricity 
generated for domestic use in 2016, with difference reflecting the fact that net exports are generally accounted 
for by gas generation, which increases the share of nuclear generation and of all renewables to 37% each, 
leaving 26% of electricity generation for domestic use dependent on imported gas.

relations.Subject: system
relations.Description:
The Armenia power system 
has interconnections with all neighbor countries, although those with Turkey and Azerbaijan were not in 
operation, due to political issues.

relations.Subject: Electricity
relations.Description:
Electricity generated by power plants and transmitted by HVL reaches consumers through the distribution 
network, which comprises 110 – 35 - 6(10) - 0.4 kV lines and cables.

relations.Subject: Figure
relations.Description:
Figure 1.4 shows the share of electricity consumption by economic sectors in 2016, using the terminology for 
sectors of the Public Services Regulatory Commission (PSRC).

relations.Subject: sectors
relations.Description:
Clearly, in terms of understanding and projecting demand growth for electricity, these three sectors will be a 
key focus for in-depth modelling.

relations.Subject: facility
relations.Description:
The underground gas storage facility in Abovyan, 
which has capacity of around 140 million cubic meters (m3), provides an opportunity to regulate daily load 
fluctuations in heavy demand periods such as winter days, as well as to accumulate some amount of gas to 
provide uninterrupted supply in emergency situations.

relations.Subject: system
relations.Description:
The bulk gas transportation system includes 1,682.2 km of main and branch gas pipelines, of which 
1,586.5 km of gas pipelines are involved in gas transportation activities and the rest is in operational reserve 
mode.

relations.Subject: facility
relations.Description:
The Abovyan gas storage facility includes 21 underground tanks and compressor 
stations.

relations.Subject: section
relations.Description:
This section presents 
the main data of the Armenian Energy Balance for the base year (2016), as officially published by International 
Energy Agency (IEA)

relations.Subject: Table
relations.Description:
Table 1.5 presents the Armenian Energy Balance for 2016, which includes also the amounts of other energy 
carriers used, in particular coal and oil.

relations.Subject: processes
relations.Description:
Transformation processes comprise the conversion of primary forms of energy to secondary and 
further transformation (e.g., coking coal to coke; crude oil to oil products; fuel oil to electricity).

relations.Subject: use

relations.Description:
